May 17 2006	RUN DOWN HOTEL	Yes, this hotel is in a great location, but beware of a hotel that is long overdue for a rehab. At first the lobby is very nice, so you expect the room to be nice, but when we walked in the room you could smell mold. The carpet needs to be replaced and the walls have been painted over many times. The A/C is a small unit in a window of the bedroom which does not cool down the living room. I left the A/C unit on to keep the room cool, but the staff turns it off after they clean, so when you get back to your room after a long day the room is hot and smells. The bathroom is very small and needs to be re-done. The sink is 6 inches away from the toilet. I know the hotel is an old building, but put a little money into your rooms to make them half way decent. I dont know what others saw in this hotel!

Apr 26 2006	Love the Monticello!!!	We just returned from a long weekend at the Monticello Inn. This is our second stay at this lovely little hotel. We love the homey atmosphere and gracious staff. The service is wonderul. The new pillow top beds are very comfortable. The rooms are clean and well maintained for an older hotel. Mini bars are well stocked and extras like irons and ironing boards are nice to have. We stay in the city several times a year, and have stayed in every major hotel. We really appreciate the service of this small hotel. We love this wonderful hotel and will return every time we go to the city.

Mar 28 2006	Wonderful Location and Room	I just returned from a 3 night stay at the Monticello Inn for a long weekend in San Francisco. Having stayed within the Kimpton chain in San Francisco previously, I had a high expectation for service that was met by all staff members I came in contact with.When I arrived, I was immediately greeted at the door and they made quick arrangements for my car to be parked (note that parking is $33 per day plus tax, which I knew about before hand and chose to pay on this trip). Since I arrived around 1 pm, I did not expect my room to be ready, but it was! This was an added bonus.I had reseved a king room with a AAA rate, but was upgraded to a suite. The suite was on the 4th floor facing the courtyard and was great. It was two rooms, with an incredibly comfortable bed and a nice sitting area in the "living room". The hotel also has free wireless internet access throughout as well as complimentary coffee service in the morning and a wine reception in the afternoon.The Monticello's location cannot be beat. My wife and I love walking around San Francisco, and from its location a block from the cable car terminus at Powell and Market, it cannot be beat.We did not try the restaurant at the hotel, but the menu and decor looked very nice.

Feb 15 2006	Great Location and Friendly Staff	My Fiance and I stayed at the Monticello Inn from Feb 11-13 and have nothing but good things to say about it. We had purchased the room on Hotwire.com and were a bit apprehensive as we had never stayed at a Kimpton Hotel before, but were very pleased. You can't beat the location... on the corner of Ellis and Powell which is literally a 30 sec walk to the cable cars (which are $5 per trip). The old-fashioned trolley cars are around the corner also a must and much cheaper at $1.50 (which includes a transfer good on any lines for 3 hrs).The staff at the hotel were extremely friendly and helpful (especially when we had to extend our stay by one night due to my fiance getting food poisioning). And the hotel was suprisingly quite, even though we were right in the heart of the city. Ask for a courtyard room if you can, we had one the first night and it was great. No noise at all, but you do lose out on any view. The only problem with the rooms was the size... but it is a boutique hotel.Another perk of the hotel is their complimentary wine-tasting every night from 5-6. The best part is you are able to take it with you to your room to sip while watching the early news! As for their contential breakfast at $6.00 - not really worth it as there are tons of bakerys and coffee shops in the neighbourhood where you can get the same stuff for half the price.Overall, I was very pleased with the hotel and would recommed it for anyone looking for great value and fantastic quality right in one of the greatest shopping meccas of the USA!

Dec 6 2005	Very good - will return	I stayed at the Monticello for 4 nights in November. I was quite pleased and plan to stay there again. On the plus side:1. Excellent downtown location.2. Extremely close to all forms of public transportation.3. Good restaurants and shopping nearby.4. My king room was very comfortable and quiet. If this important to you, ask for an inside (courtyard) room if one is available. Bed, linens, bath, etc. excellent. Tourists and residents alike know that this area of SFO is very noisy. Coming back to my room was like visiting a private oasis of cushy silence.5. No hitches with reservations, requests, etc.Some parts of the hotel could use a bit of renovation touch-up...paint here and there, door frames, wear & tear, carpet edges, etc.I didn't try the continental breakfast (minimal extra charge) but the set up looked nice.The hotel doesn't have a pool, fitness club, etc. if that's what you're looking for. They do, however, arrange for in-room yoga, massage, beauty facials, etc. for rather high prices.A very nice, comfortable stay overall.

Dec 5 2005	Monticello In - Great location	We selected the Monticello on the basis of our research on the Internet and in particular for its location to the BART. This enabled us to travel from the San Francisco International Airport to within about 150yds of the hotel. When we walked up the ramp from the BART to the the end of Powell Street we were blown away as it was our first time in San Francisco and with the cable car in front of us it was like being in a postcard. We also used Google Earth to check out its location within the city and its closeness to other facilities.The hotel was most acceptable given that we didn't want to spend our limited funds on expensive accommodation. Its location is superb. The hotel is an old hotel that has been refurbished but I wouldn't say modernised but it is clean and the staff are very friendly. The rooms are rather small but that didn't bother us as we spent most of our time out looking around the city. It is near to the corners of Market & Powell Streets which gives you immediate access to the cable car terminus, trams to the Fisherman's Wharf, Union Square and Maceys, The BART terminus and there are plenty of tourist shops and food stores nearby.If we went again we would definitely ask for a courtyard room because the noise on the street side rooms was terrible. We were jet-lagged after a trip from Australia so needed some good sleep but it was just not possible in the room we were in. So with that proviso we would definitely return.

Nov 16 2005 	WIll Be Returning to the Monticello	I travel to San Francisco on business every few months and am always looking for a better hotel deal. SF hotels are across the board on price and quality and you quickly learn that a higher price does not necessarily mean a nicer hotel or location. The Monticello Inn is well-located for tourists and business travelers alike: less than two blocks from Union Square and less than a block from the SF Mall (Nordstrom's, etc.), BART station, and several good restaurants, five to ten minute cab ride from civic center plaza or the business district.One of the biggest pluses of the Monticello (for those of us who like to have our best friends with us) is that they accept dogs (I believe the entire Kimpton chain accepts dogs). I arrived with my three 50+ pound dogs - no problem. At check-in the clerk even offered a free upgrade to a suite so that I could have more room for the dogs. Incredible; very appreciated. The suite was spacious, nicely decorated, very clean. After reading reviews here I requested an inside room and it was nice and quiet though the view is of the air vents.Staff was very friendly and always greeted my dogs as well as me.Continental breakfast in the morning for $6.50 is a true "continental" - just coffee, juice, muffins and fruit. I prefer more substance. Valet parking with in and out privileges for $29 is very reasonable for SF. Only complaint would be that valet was slow in retrieving car when I wanted it. Overall, I highly recommend this hotel and will be staying here again myself very soon.

Sep 27 2005	Excellent value	I really enjoyed The Monticello and would have no hesitation of staying there again. I had one of the Jefferson suites and found it to be very comfortable and homey. Ask for a view of the interior courtyard as there was absoultely no noise. Best things about this hotel: the service, the beds and the location. Worst things about this hotel: could not find anything. Enjoy this great value hotel.

Sep 18 2005 	Great place to stay in the center of SF	Not much to add to the previous reviews:A great location (BART, cable car, everything...)...nice decor...clean and pleasant rooms...friendly staff...wine reception...breakfast if needed (note that there are also many Starbucks around)...free wireless internet and newspaper.Not really negative points but be aware of:Rooms towards front will be noisy...rooms towards the back are absolutely quiet but the view of brick walls is somewhat depressing...low shower pressure...why no pictures on the wall?Advice: we got the Monticello for an amazing price in a package deal with Expedia.

Sep 15 2005	Monticello Inn Was a Pleasant Stay	I traveled to San Francisco with my sister who was attending a business convention at the Marriott. This little boutique hotel was quite charming and very close to the public transportation I chose - the BART station for to and from the SFO airport, and the cable cars for to and from the wharf areas. Very clean room and bath. We were not able to attend their wine reception one night, and a nice man on staff was able to produce a glass for each of us. They provided continental breakfast vouchers for us. This proved a great time saver for us on the days that we just wanted to get out and get started on our sightseeing days. It was very handy to grab a muffin, croissant, juice and coffee as we hurried out for our busy days. I did not dine at the restaurant on site, nor did we order room service. There is a Subway sandwich shop right next door. Very close proximity to Union Square shopping - which can be a good or bad thing! I would recommend this hotel to anyone.

Sep 6 2005	I would definately stay there again!	Great location, clean, sophisticated hotel, and good quality bed and professional staff. The hotel provides the quality and comfort. Definately a good place to stay!

Aug 31 2005 	Excellent Service -Average Accommodations	We just returned from a week in San Francisco. We chose the Monticello based primarily on Kimpton's pet friendly policies and the hotel's proximity to the Moscone Convention Center. We were graciously welcomed and our little dog developed a huge fan club. The front desk staff consistently went above and beyond the normal 3 star call of duty by providing us with directions - calling cabs - giving us restaurant recommendations and helping with reservations. They were also great about keeping our cell phone number on hand just in case our little dog got distressed and started barking or something during the few occassions we left him alone in the room. The room was average - nothing special though. We booked a Jefferson suite, so it was nice to have the extra space. The bathroom was a little worn and could use some updating, but it was clean and well kept during the course of our visit. I can't say I'm a big fan of the dispensers for soap and shampoo and whatnot, but I'm sure that the environment is (at least that's what the little sign said.) The only problem (and I can't say that it was an insignificant one) that we had with our room was street noise. We were on the second floor (the only pet friendly floor) and the noise was pretty bad. Being near an intersection, we heard a lot of sirens and brakes squealing. Every morning around 3 a.m., the street sweepers and trash trucks came through. The staff was apologetic and we realized, of course, that it was out of their control. They could not move us to another floor because of the dog and all of the inside rooms were already booked, so we made the best of it. Thankfully, we always travel with a white noise machine and that helped somewhat. We would definitely consider staying at the hotel again, but next time we would specify that we wanted a room as far away from the street as possible.

Jul 20 2005	Great location good value	My husband and I stayed at the Monticello Inn for four nights while on our honeymoon. The staff was friendly and always helpful. The rooms were small but clean. The breakfast was horrible (toast and coffee, some mornings there were small muffins and old bananas) and we wouldn't recommend paying for breakfast. The location is great for shopping, eating and site-seeing, especially if you're getting around the city on foot or by cable car.

Jul 17 2005 	A Hidden Gem	I stayed at the Monticellno Inn for 4 nights for a big conference that took up over 50% of hotels in San Francisco. This hotel was not my original choice. My office booked this hotel for me because my three hotel preferences were sold out (Hotel Monaco, Grand Hyatt, W). I kept an open mind upon check in. The hotel just completed renovation in all rooms. I had a suite on the top floor. It was nicely decorated, stocked with a good variety of magazines, and the staff was very pleasant. There was some steet noise but I did not have trouble sleeping. The showerhead is the "water saver" model that could use more pressure and water volume. The complimenary wireless internet was convenient and worked well. There was no coffee maker in the room, but I was able to get good fresh coffee from the lobby every morning. The public areas have new furnitures, comfortable and inviting, and were kept cleaned at all times. Liked the free newspaper in the lobby (San Francisco Chronicle, Financial Times, The Examiner). The afternoon wine hour was a very nice touch and enjoyable. Requested wake up calls every day, but only received 2 calls out of the 4 requests. I used the bedside alarm clock as a back-up so it worked out fine. The valet parking at $30 per day is reasonable when compared to other nearby hotels that charge $35 and up. The $6.50 continental breakfast was convenient at the hotel library lounge, which is a more pleasant place to have breakfast than the noisy crowds and dirty tables at Starbuck or greasy diners. The location is one of the best, cable car around the corner, and walking distance to the Moscone center and shops. Special acknowlegement goes to Ms. Tammy Tran for the great renovation, and Ms. Cue Li of taking care of my accommodation request. The Monticello Inn is a hidden gem and I highly recommend it if you don't need to be in a "name brand" and/or "trendy" hotel and you enjoy an inn that offers an unassuming ambience, quiet elegance with early American charm.

Jun 25 2005	Great location 	I stayed at the Monticello based on reviews from Trip Advisor. I was a bit concerned that the reviews varied but I couldn't beat the price of $109US per night. The reviews probably vary becauase the room are most definitely 'tired'. But they are clean and attractive. The location is unbeatable. Minutes to Union Square & around the corner from the trolly & BART (30minutes directly to the airport - unbelievable $$savings!!). The corner room I got was twice the size of the pictures posted here & the shampoo/conditioner/soap were high quality. Staff were very friendly - I never waited for service - early check-in/late check-out & they stored our bags while we were out of the room but not yet ready for our flight. The $6.50 per room! breakfast was well worth it for a quick morning snack. Much more affordable than the greasy $20 diner breakfast around the corner. My biggest complaint was that the air conditioning didn't work. HOWEVER - I was advised that the entire hotel would have new units by Aug05. Once that's updated I would definitely choose the Monticello.

May 31 2005	Great Location Decent hotel	My wife and I stayed at the Monticello Inn for two nights from May 28-30 (Memorial Day weekend). I paid $107 a night for a queen-bed room. we got a free upgrade to a king-bed. Great Location - 1 block from Union Square, close to the Cable car, bus line, restaurants, shopping areas. The room was small, but thats OK since we hardly spent any time indoors (except for sleeping and showering). The room had a peculiar odour too. The room AC took a long while to cool the room. The bathrooms are small. No coffee maker in the room. There was no street noise. The hotel provides breakfast for a nominal fee, but we preferred Subway (right next door) and starbucks (one block away). The hotel staff is friendly and very courteous. Hotel provides valet parking for $30 a day (quite expensive). All in all, this is a decent place to stay if you are going to be visiting SFO for a few days.

May 17 2005	Beautiful simplicity	We have stayed here for two nights when attending my brother-in-law's wedding. The wedding itself was in the Sir Francis Drake Hotel, but I booked the Monticello as it had better reviews and I had a corporate discount. And it was about five minutes from the wedding location on foot.The location is excellent, and compared to other hotels, the noise level was lower, as it is off Powell Street (one block). Now, if you are living in the suburbs and never had a chance to get used to city environment, you might have trouble falling asleep as San Francisco IS a noisy city. We had another couple with us staying at the same hotel for the wedding, and they had sleep trouble, never having lived in a city.The hotel itself is VERY charming and the decor is really nice. I never quite understood complaints about small bathrooms or not being able to see television from the bed...I do not like chain hotels, I grew up poor, and this hotel reminded me some of the grand old hotels in my hometown in Central Europe. Yes, the rooms are small, and the bathrooms have some cracks and the paint might be chipped, but really...does this mater when you are sightseeing all day and you get to your room at oh-dark-thirty at night, ready to collapse? The furnishings might have been old, but everything was spotless clean.The staff was very, very accomodating. When after the wedding, we were in a crunch for time, and my husband realized that we could not return the rented tails he wore, the hotel staff offered to help us out and returned it that afternoon.The breakfast is $6.50 per room, not per person, and as such, is a really good value in the Union Square area of the town. Good croissants, orange juice and strong coffee, and the muffins were nice and fresh as well.The only thing we winced about was the valet parking price...but again, when remembering that this is San Francisco downtown, it's understandable.We will definitely stay here again when visiting.

May 8 2005	Monticello Inn-A great place to stay	We found the Monticello Inn a great place to stay in San Francisco. The location is excellent - near Union Square, just around the corner from the cable car turnaround (be sure to ride holding on to the side, it's more fun than you'd imagine), BART and the tram to Fisherman's Wharf. The staff was friendly and accomodating, to the extent that when we registered they brought each of us a glass of wine since we had missed the wine reception.The rooms are small but comfortable, with very nice beds and linens. We'd certainly stay here again.

Apr 12 2005	okay stay	My husband and I went up to the city for a one night stay. We searched on line for something close to Union Square, but not too expensive. We booked on the hotel's website for a breakfast package for $149 which included breakfast and parking. However, upon checkout, we were told that parking and breakfast were not included. They comped us the breakfast for a whopping $6.50 which is an outrageous price for croissants and muffins, coffee and juice. Checkout was not the right time to find out that they weren't going to pay for parking. Parking was $30. The total bill with tax and everything ended up being $200. This was not a $200 hotel!The location was GREAT! Couldn't be more convenient to Union Square. Right next to the cable car. Easy to get a cab. Just perfect location.The room itself was HUGE, but very poorly laid out. It was very difficult to watch TV from the bed, but impossible to watch it from the chairs. We had to sit on the bed in order to watch it. We couldn't lie in bed and watch TV. The bathroom was terribly tiny with barely enough room to turn around in. It is an eco-friendly hotel. So, everything was in dispenser's. Soap, shampoo, lotion, etc. I understand and am thrilled with this concept as it isn't so wasteful. However, the dispenser's didn't work that well. You either got a lot or a little, but never the right amount. If location is the most important thing to you, this is the place to stay, but that's the only reason.

Mar 17 2005 	Nice hotel; good location	I stayed one night at the Monticello Inn in March 2005. The hotel was nicely decorated and gave the impression of a charming old inn. Pulling up out front for valet parking was crowded. Valet kept our car directly under the hotel which was very convenient. The morning continental breakfast for $6.50 was good but some hotels offer this for free. The room had a few problems: there was not a desk for my computer when using the internet connection, so I used the bed as a make-shift desk; the bathroom sink smelled like moldly laundry, although it appeared to be clean; the conditioner pump in the shower was empty, which I discovered while in the shower when I REALLY needed it; the "touch" lamp near the bed kept going on and off; the lights dimmed when more than one electrical device was being used. The room was moderately quiet but you could hear street noise. NOTE: For those of you not familiar with San Francisco, all hotel rooms will be noisy to some extent, even when they advertise quiet rooms. I have never stayed at one where I did not hear street noise. This is a big city with old buildings and even new, double paned windows will let noise through. If any noise bothers you, then either don't stay in the City or ask for an inner, no view room which may help. The location was awesome within walking distance to many things. I would stay again but prefer a hotel with a more modern feel.

Mar 4 2005 	Great Location; Good Price	Stayed there for a week in February 2005 during a business trip. The location is wonderful. You're within easy walking distance of a lot of attractions, including the cable car stations. Lots of shopping in nearby Union Square. I flew in from Oakland and found the BART perfect -- drops you a block from the hotel at the Powell Street station. The nightly wine tastings in the library were a real treat. Well attended while I was there and a great way to meet others. Missed the Wednesday night book reading. I signed up for the morning continental breakfast and think I got my money's worth. $6 doesn't buy you much elsewhere in SF. Downsides if you're there for business: Wireless service was lousy. My cell didn't work well in my room, which faced the courtyard. Too much concrete between me and the cell tower. Also, they offer high speed thru wireless but I needed a special device that they were out of the week I was there so I couldn't do my work at night, had to find another location. The price was right; the staff superb. Highly recommend it, especially for pleasure travelers.

Feb 26 2005	Very Noisy	My husband and I stayed here for a week: Dec 12-18, 2004. We are not very picky people - we are grad students, and have slept in very humble accomodations in many countries, and enjoy camping. However, when one pays $129/night, one expects a decent hotel stay.Pros: Location (right by Union Square); Free Internet Access; some Aveda bathroom products.Neutral: 5-6pm Happy Hour. The wine was not very good, and the lobby was so crowded. (We were there during a science conference, so it was a lot of young people trying to maximize their wine consumption during the 60 minute happy hour - kind of overwhelming if you do not like crowds). The corn bread was nice, though.Major Con: the noise. We could not sleep. There was construction going on outside our room ALL NIGHT, every night! In one way you could say this was not the hotel's fault; however, their odd window situation makes it their fault. Our room had 2 windows, and in each there was an AC unit (that doubled as a heater) that could not be removed. It was semi-built-in. Therefore, the windows were permanently open. My husband had to present at the science conference, and could not get a good night's sleep. We bought earplugs, we complained (requested a room on the inside corridor, but none available), we turned on the AC fans just to drown out the noise. Nothing worked. I would caution a business traveler NOT to stay here if you need to be alert the next day. The street noise is severe even absent the construction, and the walls are paper thin. You can hear people in the hallway and the next room.I politely complained while I was there, and they did not solve the problem. They sent me an email survey after our stay, and I told them what I'm writing here. They sent an apology email, but no discount offer for another Kimpton Hotel.

Feb 3 2005	Great location Great Price 	Stayed here for two nights as our first taste of the States. Very easy to get to from the airport being less than a 100 metres from a BART station. Check-in was easy and the staff friendly. We had two rooms that were close to each other, one for the adults and one for the kids. The rooms had a good arrangement with a lounge room and bedroom w/ensuite neatly separated by the entry, turn one way for the lounge, turn the other for the bed. With TV's in each this meant both kids could watch their shows without disturbing the other. The rooms were also nicely furnished and although the bathrooms were old style and smallish, they were part of the history of the place...take it as charm. The hotel is well located on Ellis just off Powell and the cable car route and it is quiet. Our other hotel choice was the Villa Florence which is well rated but some reviews complain of noise and it is easy to see why as it is right on Powell. If you want to be confronted by the evening throng of street scammers as you leave the hotel then stay there. The Monticello is much quieter and allows you to get your bearings in peace and then blend in.

Jan 19 2005	Charming Small Hotel; Unbeatable Location Near Cable Cars	I stayed at the Monticello Inn for six nights, Jan. 4-10, 2005, with my daughter and her friend. I attended a major conference in San Francisco in early January and did not want to stay at any of the three large conference hotels nearby. After reading the reviews on this site, I booked a Jefferson Suite directly with the hotel rather than using one of the online travel reservation sites. Later I emailed the hotel and changed my original check-in date from January 3 to January 4, and received a prompt and courteous email response confirming that our reservation had been changed to check in on Jan. 4. When we arrived at the hotel at about 1:30 pm on Jan. 4, the desk clerk told me the reservation had been cancelled completely. I tersely told the clerk that I had booked directly with the hotel to be sure I would not have any problems with making the reservation through one of the online services. He responded that "none of the guarantees apply" if a reservation is made through an online service. Once again I firmly reminded him that was exactly why I had made my reservation directly with the hotel. After this exchange, he managed to "work us in" to a Jefferson Suite on the fifth floor -- the top floor of the hotel. I then specifically requested a room on the courtyard side where it would be more quiet. He confirmed it was a courtyard suite and cautioned us it was the best he had available. After this snafu, the rest of our stay was very nice. The room was a good size two-room suite. Many of the furnishings appeared to be new, although some of the living area upholstery was a little worn. The bathroom was small but adequate, with bath soap, shampoo, and conditioner in dispensers near the sink and in the shower. The fixtures (sink and tub) were worn, and the tile around the shower needed some minor repairs. Basic toiletries (bar soap, shower cap, sewing kit) were never replaced the entire six-day stay. White and red wine was served in the charming lobby every evening from 5:00 to 6:00. The lobby was graced with comfortable seating and two fireplaces. The service throughout our stay was friendly and accommodating. Although the hotel has no ice machines accessible to guests, every time we asked for ice or something else (coffee pot, another robe, more towels) our request was addressed promptly and courteously (without tipping). The king-size bed was exceptionally comfortable, and the wireless high-speed internet access worked flawlessly -- a welcome change from some hotels. Best of all, the Inn's location is unbeatable. Powell Street is a short half-block away, and Union Street shopping is just a couple of blocks north of the hotel. I walked a short block each day to and from the huge conference hotel and was so glad I was staying in a smaller, friendlier, much more charming hotel. If you have time for sightseeing, buy a 3-day or 7-day pass ($ 20) at the visitor's center a just a block south of the hotel, and ride the cable cars, buses, and muni-trains as much as you wish. We found a Mediterranean restaurant one block north of the hotel with very good food for the price, an inexpensive Thai restaurant one block away on Powell, and great sushi at a second-floor restaurant on the corner right across the street from the hotel. Great food at very reasonable prices for San Francisco! Overall, we had a delightful stay, and we were impressed with the friendly and very helpful staff. The next time I visit downtown San Francisco, I will look forward to staying at the Monticello Inn again.

Jan 10 2005	great place	we stayed at the monticello sep 03. its got a lovely reception area, with free tea/coffee available pretty much all day, with a free wine reception one night a week too. our room was a good size, with a massive bed and the bathroom was pretty massive too, with a full size window which opened out onto a view of downtown (bit weird to sit in the bathroom looking out the window, i know, but it was actually quite fun sitting on the windowsill watching people go by). the hotel has a good location, only 5mins from the cable car terminus and union sq. so yes, it can be a little noisy at night as the cable car goes by, but hey you're in the city, what do you expect? all in all, good hotel right in the centre for a reasonable price!

Jan 5 2005	Good value great location	Stayed at the Monticello over Memorial Day weekend 2004. Was genuinely surprised and pleased that the room we reserved turned out to be a suite. I wasn't expecting that. Staff was very friendly and helpful, from replacing our mini-bar when the key broke off in it (!), to addressing a plumbing issue with a tempermental toliet, to securing our bags after checking out while we toured the city on our last day in town, to arranging for our shuttle ride to the airport. Also very convienent to the cable car terminus and other public transportation. All-in-all, a good experience.

Dec 24 2004	This is a two-star hotel and not worth full price.	I travel frequently for business and in general have had good experience with the Kimpton chain. This hotel, however, was disappointing. I spoke at some length with the front desk before booking online, and was told it was a 3-star, newly renovated, and breakfast was included. I don't know who I spoke to, but none of this turned out to be true. This hotel plays the 'put you in a crappy room and see if you complain game', a ploy also mentioned by other reviewers. They do follow through with the fix or upgrade but I dislike these games. Most of the hotel is not newly renovated, and features stains on the substandard carpets, linens, and towels. Beds are lumpy and should be replaced. Staff is friendly but often never quite manages to solve the problem, in that very two star way. I slept the first two nights in rooms with no heat, finally after the third room move they gave me a space heater. I appreciated the solution but not the time involved in moving several times on a business trip. The lobby is nice, and wine tasting is a decent touch, but they need to forget about the frills and get back to basics, like a decent bed, a renovated bathroom, and a floor that doesn't make a person cringe. If you book in advance, online, you can get a room for $99/night. I wouldn't pay more than that. Considering it as a two-star in that price range, I would say it's average. What I disliked was the misrepresentation at the time of booking. Overall, this is an ok two-star hotel, but not worth full price.

May 29 2009 	A good place to stay in San Francisco	MollettsBrisbane, AustraliaMay 29, 2009My husband and I, together with our 30 year old daughter have just spent 7 nights at this hotel. On a previous visit to SF my husband and I stayed at a hotel further down Sutter Street but did discover the bar and restaurant at the Beresford. The restaurant was good value and good homestyle food so imagine my disappointment when we arrived to be told that the restaurant has been closed for the past couple of months for renovation and is not due to open again until later in June. The bar was still open however and our daughter enjoyed her evenings there with the friendly bartender (female) and she was able to meet people around her own age. There is also a happy hour (?) from 5.30 - 8.30pm with free hot appetisers, consisting mainly of hot dogs and I think meatballs but we didn't avail ourselves of these. I have to say that the on-site restaurant was the main reason we decided to stay at this hotel but that was our only disappointment. The staff was friendly and helpful (although there seemed to be someone different every time we went to the lobby) and the rates were very reasonable. We had a room with two double beds on the 7th floor in the front of the hotel. I would not advise staying in this part of the hotel as it is very noisy. There is no air conditioning so the windows were left open. Ask for a room at the back. The room itself was comfortable which is all we ask for in a hotel - cleanliness and a comfortable bed and of course a safe area. The location of the hotel is excellent - 1 block to Powell Street and the cable cars and another block to Union Square. There are many great places to eat in SF - we found the Italian on the corner (Cesarios) to be very good and Lori's Diner is a block away. A continental breakfast is included in the rate and it is OK but I find Krispy Kreme donuts for breakfast a bit much. There was cereal, croissants and fresh fruit so we didn't need to have the sugary donuts and danishes. If you are looking for 5 star luxury this hotel is certainly not it but as other reviewers have said it has an old-world feel. There is also free internet access but for some reason neither our daughter nor I could access our emails. The management at the time didn't seem very interested in fixing the problem and for the first few days we seemed to get limited television access but these are minor problems. I would certainly recommend the Beresford for location and value.

May 20 2009 	Good Location Poor Plumbing and Fire Safety	We stayed here in March 2009 as part of an organised tour - the accomodation had been booked by a tour company.The location of the hotel is very good and all central shopping areas, restaurants and transport are within easy walking distance. Our first problem on arrival was that the key they gave us for the room would not open the door so someone came with another key and this would not open the door either, a third key and we were in. My first thought was to check the fire escape arrangements and there was an external fire escape at the front of the hotel which could be accessed from each corridor and this was fine but the fire escape from the rear part of the upper floors was through two bedrooms on each floor. As the doors were locked I went I went down to the Front Desk and asked how we would get to the Rear Fire Exit in an emergency through the locked doors - he did not know so I asked for the Manager and was told she was not available so I left a message for her to contact me. We then went out for the evening and when we returned we found that the taps would not work so I phoned the front desk and was informed that we had to turn on the valves under the sink - as these could not be turned they sent a member of staff who also could not turn these valves on. We then had to move rooms with no help from hotel staff and when we ran water into the sink the plug would not let the water out and part of the plumbing from behind the sink fell onto the floor. When I went down to the Front Desk I was given a handful of keys and was told to go and choose a room where everything worked. As the Manager had not come back to me about the fire exit problem I selected on of the rooms which lead directly to the rear fire escape.I also approached the travel company representative who was also staying in the hotel and she indicated that it was nothing to do with her and could I let her have my comments in writing which I did. By the time we left no one was able to answer how we would be able to use the fire escape so on my return I wrote to the travel company again and to the San Francisco Fire Department who have also not replied. I also copied my letter to the Mayor of San Francisco who also has not replied so if you stay here just ask yourself how you will get out in a fire?

Oct 9 2008 	Great Deal for simple and charming experience	Got this hotel through cheap tickets.comI was worried because of some more negative reviews, but I was actually impressed when I got there. So, I just enjoyed being able to stay in a building that was not built yesterday. The furnishings are old and ugly, but somehow charming (like an ugly dog that seems cute). Also, the breakfasts in the little pub downstairs offered a nicer fare than your regular continental breakfasts.Traveling in March, I did not notice any problems with the lack of A/C in the building. We did sleep with the windows open all night which made for a comfortable breeze. Although, the college dorms across the street the and pub guests down below were somewhat noisy, I was able to sleep just fine. My dad was more bothered by it than I was. I think the noise of the town became more like white noise for me. It's never quiet...but it's the city afterall. It was close to the cable cars which gave you quick access to all the attractions. There is no need to worry about transportation in this city! Only on one day did we rent a car to check out places further from town (Muir Woods, coastline, and Golden Gate Park). I wouldn't want to have to park a car on the streets more than I had to...those hills are scary steep:DMy whole reason for this trip was to see a She and Him concert. This portion of my trip was a bit trickier because the venue was not in the nicest part of town. A quick cab ride solved any of my reservations about walking the few blocks. If you are looking for a luxury experience I would not recommend this hotel. If you are looking to enjoy the charm of this city and not pay out the rear, then this is a great place to stay!

Apr 27 2008 	Great value charming character	Hotel Beresford is not going to win any luxury awards. The rooms are indeed small, at least the cheap ones. However, I loved my stay there! It was refreshingly different from the plain vanilla hotels you can find anywhere in the US.What you can expect: - Charm and character: The carpets are deep red. The light fixtures are crystal. The elevator has etched mirrors inside. Each room is decorated differently, and yeah, it felt a little like staying at my grandma's house, what with the two double beds in a room big enough for one queen, but I enjoyed it. - Good value: Our room was just over $100/night, including taxes. You can hardly beat that in San Francisco, and being right next to Union Square we could walk to most of what we wanted to see and easily take buses or cable car to the rest.- Safety: We were two single women wandering around San Francisco, but arriving back to the hotel made us feel right at home and safe. It's in a decent neighborhood; we walked a few blocks in all four directions at various times. The restaurants around the hotel are either expensive or small and cheap. There's a swanky Mexican place two blocks away, or for chain food, a diner two blocks in the other direction. There's a corner Walgreen's nearby too, for essentials you forget; not as cheap as in the 'burbs, but cheaper than the airport or a convenience store. - Good food: The restaurant in the hotel had delicious food at a reasonable price; we two split a leg of lamb, an appetizer, and drinks for $40. Make sure you check the hours (only open for dinner, and not on Sundays) -- but it was great the one night we came home without the energy to look around. The continental breakfast was fruit, cereal, and pastries, with milk, juice, tea and coffee -- nothing impressive but enough to fill us up and get us going in the morning.What not to expect: - Internet: There's an old, slow computer in the lobby which might last long enough to check your e-mail on, but you'll have to wait in line for it.- Things to be new: The whole building is old. The rooms are old, so the windows and bathroom fixtures and furniture are also old. I felt it was clean enough (I wasn't afraid to stand on the carpet or in the shower), but it didn't look new. - Spaciousness: We were only in the room to sleep, and there was plenty of room for that. Four people in our room would have been tight, but it was billed as two twin beds (they were actually doubles; twins would've made the room feel bigger) so I hope you don't TRY to put four people into it. Overall, I recommend it for people who are planning to be out and about all day and want a nice place to come back to.

Mar 29 2008 	Excellent Value for Money	We stayed for 3 nights in early March 2008. We had not expected breakfast so the coffee, pastries and fruit were a great bonus if you wanted to get out quickly. The wine and cheese were also enjoyable if you got back in time. Mar 22 2008 	Great location shame about the hotel...	I have just returned from a week's holiday staying at this hotel. While the rooms seemed clean there was a terrible smell of rubbish on our floor of the hotel (clearly from bins that had been left in the corridor after being removed from the bathrooms). Jan 27 2008 	Great value and location for the money	we stayed at the hotel beresford for two weeks and overall enjoyed our stay there. the location is great and the hotel is worth the money. the building is quite old as is the interior. but it is relatively cheap, you get a clean room, which is not noisy and in a great spot.breakfast comes on styropor plates and cups, comprises of cereal, danish pastries and fruit, and is presented in a very simple way.we had no tv and there was no wifi available, but there was a computer with internet connection available for free next to the reception. however, this single computer was occupied most of the time so that we decided to take our laptops into the sugar cafe a few doors up the road which is a great designer cafe for coffe, cake and free internet.

Jan 22 2008 	good value for the price	We stayed at the Hotel Beresford for 4 nights at the beginning of October. We booked far in advance which is a good thing since it was Fleet week.The hotel is very conveniently located if you are a tourist (as we were). The cable car is a 3 minute walk away and there are also buses running right past the hotel. Union Square is a short walk away and Chinatown is also within walking distance. There are lots of places to eat nearby. The hotel itself is good value for money. We were actually amazed to find such a reasonable place so close to the centre of town.The staff were very friendly and helpful. The room was medium sized and the bed was comfortable. The bathroom was OK, the minibar well stocked and not expensive and there was plenty of wardrobe space.Breakfast was served in the restaurant on the ground floor. Nov 6 2007 	Decent Hotel for the money	I booked this hotel for 5 nights and for the most part enjoyed it. Great location to Union Square and many dining options within walking distance. Oct 26 2007 	It takes some getting use to	The building is old, the rooms are small, and functional. But the rooms are clean, quiter than I expected, and the staff very helpful. Good locationwith many good places to eat nearby.Great deal for the price.

Oct 18 2007 	Not recommended; add a few bucks and stay elsewhere	First of all, it is important to emphasize that different sites rate this hotel differently, the rating varying between two-star, three-star and even "boutique", which, for all I know, usually stands for "a two-star property at a four-star rate". There is a lot of homeless folks soliciting donations and sleeping on the sidewalk right next to the hotel, and quite a few cheap food and wine joints attracting way too much attention until very late hours. The hotel is old. It looks old and worse than that smells old. The lobby is tiny with just three chairs and a small coffee table. The staff tries their best, but they do not speak too much English and are sometimes hard to understand. We have been given a tiny room in the middle of a corridor, with a window facing a loud AC exhaust of the neighboring building just several feet away. After lengthy discussions, we were able to get another room facing Post St., in the third floor. The room was tiny, too, and the bathroom was literally three by six feet. Certain acrobatics skills were required to use the toilet. The shower unit was worn, but the water pressure excellent. There was a tiny broken TV and a little portable fan in the room. The bed was very short and way too soft. Although it was not even summer, we needed to open the window during the night hours to get some fresh air, bu this solution was far from ideal due to excessive street noise. Oct 14 2007 	Convenient location	If you're planning on spending most of your day exploring the city and just need a place to sleep at night then this hotel is for you. Oct 14 2007 	my scottish adventure	I stayed at the Beresford for 7 nights and had a fantastic time in San Francisco.Went to Monster Park to see the 49ers play the ravens,went to Alcatraz which is a must and if you want to walk across the Golden Gate Bridge it will take you around 40 minutes one way.There is an Irish bar called Lefty o' Doul's on Geary street 2 blocks down which is brilliant,met loads of irish,my own country men and many folks from Baltimore as they were playing the 49ers.Lefty's has live music every night which is fun although i went outside for a cigarette and got hassled by the homeless,don't give them any money as they will keep coming back.The Tenderloin disrict which is the bad part of San Francisco is not far away.Outside the Hotel turn right,walk 2 blocks along and walk down Powell and that will take you to the heart of Union Square.If you go left you are walking towards the Tenderloin.The Hotel staff are friendly and can't do enough for you,if you come back late at night the Hotel is locked,you just have to ring the bell and someone will let you in.There is a bar next door called The White Horse which opens at 5:30 where you can have a beer and have you're dinner at a very reasonable price.You also have a free continental breakfast there from 7 till 10-30.The rooms are small but clean,depending which room you are staying it can be noisy at night.A public transport ticket is $18 for 3 days but it is a great city for walking in.I walked to Fishermans Wharf through Chinatown and it took me 25mins,depending which way you go it can be VERY hilly.Overall i loved my stay in san Francisco which was my first time in the United States.I made many friends and felt very safe as i was on my own and would recommend this hotel and would use it again if i come back

Aug 16 2007 	Would stay here again Great hotel 	Great hotel for the price!!Yes the room furniture maybe eclectic , but who cares! Aug 14 2007 	Quaint and Great	First time to SF. Where else would you find a clean, comfortable city centre hotel with character for $107 a night, including breakfast? Stayed 4 nights, room 504. Better than you would expect from pricer establishments.Don't know breakfast was included until we checked in, a real bonus, has strawberries to die for.White Horse pub looked and felt like an English pub, very popular with people walking in off the street.Car valet service, advised to expect 20 mins, sometimes quicker, sometimes slower, although parking out front could be a problem at times.Weather was quite cold during our visit, even for SF, so central heating was turned on some nights, not really needed, aircon easy to operate, open the window.One issue that needs sorting, ventilation or lack off in resturant/breakfast room. Had to open the fire exit doors each morning, not always popular, just to get some air.Overall, if in SF again will return and can certainly recommend as excellent value for money

Jul 23 2007	A Gem for the Money Location 	This hotel is very "European," meaning the rooms are not all uniform, it's comfortable, but not fancy & it has a relatively small elevator, which did not bother us at all. Furthermore, a lot of Europeans seem to be guests. We paid the AAA rate of $108 a day & stayed in room 716, top floor corner in the back, for 6 nights. It was not a small room & had cross window ventilation & it was quiet. We also stayed for one Thursday night in room 604, which was smaller w/ one window. It was ok, but definitely not as nice as 716. Both had queen beds. It seems that all the rooms have different sizes & views(although I think there are no great views, but we weren't there for that). Of course, room 716 had more light than 604 because there were 2 windows. The staff was helpful & friendly. The breakfast was fine for us. From 7-10 there was coffee, tea, cereal, juice, croissants & pasteries & fruit, including great strawberries. The best part about the hotel for us(besides the location, which is very central & safe& about 2 1/2 blocks from Union Sq.), was the White Horse Tavern/Pub on the 1st floor. We found it to be quaint, charming, reasonably priced, w/ good food & very friendly. There is no a/c, which is normal in this city & is not a problem unless you hit a heatwave. We didn't; it was about 65 every day. The parking was $24 a day, which is about average & the only problem is that it is valet, so you do have to find a place to park for the valet(there is only 1 spot in front of the hotel for them. there are some meters & you could park in front of the hotel next door if you had to. We didn't really have a problem w/ this, but we only had the car 3 days while we were there). Also, you have to call for your car 20 minutes before you want it. The bathrooms were not huge, but we made do. There seemed to be all types of people there from families, to couples, to friends, to single travelers. To sum up, if you're staying for more than 3 days, try to get a larger corner room. Overall, we just loved the place.Tips: There is a French Restaurant, Cafe Claude, nearby on a very small street (right before Kearny)Claude Lane, off Sutter, very French, good & reasonable.  The Hotel Rex is nearby on Sutter w/ nice bar that reminded me of a small version of the Algonquin Hotel bar in NYC.  Also, you can catch the cable cars on Mason & Sutter &, I believe, Powell & Sutter, not far from the hotel.If parking is an issue, there are several motels on Lombard St., near the Marina, that have free parking. They all seemed fine. One that I noticed was Cow Hollow Motor Inn.

Jul 22 2007 	The best of the old hotels?	We stayed at the Beresford after changing our plans for another hotel that did very poorly on Tripadvisor reviews. The location is great, especially if you have no car. Keep in mind that this is a heritage building. Much of the plasterwork is presevered. The hotel is like an older movie star - you are delighted to be in her prescence and are ready to forgive the odd wrinkle due to age. The reception was efficient including giving directions with a smile. A more than adequate self-serve breakfast was served in the historic lobby. The guest rooms are conversions but clean and well cared for. This is one of the more ecomonic hotels in San Fran and you get more than your money's worth.

Jul 15 2007 	This is a real find!!	If you want a good, clean, friendly, and very well located hotel in the heart of San Francisco close to Union Square then this is it.No frills, but what are you staying in the middle of this vibrant and bustling unique American city for? Rooms are clean, it is styled with an eye on perhaps better days but I quite liked the feeling the hotel has, and the rooms are well sized, and considering we stayed here for 8 nights it was comfortable, and definately where i will stay next time i am in San Francisco. Breakfast is laid out with pastries, croissants, cereals, coffee, and decaf, plus hot water and tea bags. Milk regular, and skimmed (they call it fat free), plus cream. Plenty of fresh fruit.Help yourself, and it can't be moaned about really. Set us up for a good days sight seeing, shopping, eating, drinking, and a good base.Its interesting looking at previous reviews. Had breakfast one morning in the hotel and after that ate out - the cereals are a little too sweet for the english tastebuds and I wasn't keen on plastic plates ! According to him who must be obeyed (in his dreams) the Bloody Marys served in the bar are to recommendedHad a mini bar in the room which had a very reasonable dry white wine for $10 per bottle - although there a couple of shops a couple of doors away Several restaurants within easy walking distanceCan recomment Cesario's which is the Italian on the corner down the hill from the hotel. May 20 2007 	Visit SF not your hotel room	We were repeat visitors to the Beresford recently, this time to attend a graduation. Yes, the rooms are small and there are no views, but the price is right, the rooms are clean, the continental breakfast is free, and the front desk is helpful. May 13 2007 	Nightmare Room	There are many wonderful hotels in San Francisco with beautiful views, that are clean, quiet and that have comfortable beds. Hotel Beresford is not one of them.The lobby of this circa 1910 hotel is quaint and there is a charming little restaurant in one of the rooms where the continental breakfast (juice,cereal,fruit & pastries) is held. Then there are the rooms....The first room they gave me had an unusual odor and when I opened the door, the blast from the noise in the street was too much. The street was very busy and there was some type of work being done so I asked for another room. But at least this one had a view out the window!My stay was for two nights, so I wanted it to be a pleasant experience. When I walked in to the second room, I thought someone had left the air conditioning on. There is no air conditioning. The window was open and since the days were about 60 at the highest, I wanted some heat. There is no heat, until the radiator comes on when the hotel decides. That's very late in the evening and in the morning. There's nothing you can do! So, they gave me a space heater. I was told when I wasn't using it to turn it off since it affects everyone elses electricity! Oh, and you have to ask for a blow dryer.The room (and other rooms on this side of the building) overlook some type of generator that stays on 24/7. That's why I thought the a/c was on, because it was so loud. It was impossible to get used to! Then the tiny refrigerator reset itself every few hours while I was asleep and woke me up. And to add insult to injury, when I finally fell asleep, someone had left the alarm on the night before which woke me up a couple of hours before I'd planned to wake up. But the neighbors shower and faucet would hhave woken me up anyway. I asked 3 times to be given a different room, but they never got back to me. So, I need to give this review so that you can pick someplace better. The location was very good and the price. But you get what you pay for. Oh, I forgot to mention that my "view" was of a brick wall of the building nnext door. However, there is a small Italian restaurant at the corner of this hotel, that is absolutely outstanding. From the bread, to the meal to the service, this is a wonderful restaurant.Enjoy S.F.!

May 2 2007	Exactly what you need in San Francisco	Excellent Hotel. The best thing about this hotel is the location. It's exactly where you want to be when you are in San Francisco! You are IN Union Square a few meters from all the stores and shopping you could ever want. As well, you are 2 blocks from the historic tram which will take you directly to Fisherman's Wharf. It's walking distance to Chinatown, North Beach, the museums and even Fisherman's Wharf if you so choose. The hotel itself was much better than I expected given the very affordable price. The room was big enough and very clean, the bathroom was very adequate and the staff were helpful. There was a very reasonably priced mini bar in the room, which made it actually worth it. There is a breakfast, but it is very mediocre.The only small glitch is that the hotel restaurant closes its kitchen at 9:30. So if after a full day of traipsing around the wonderful city that is San Francisco you just want to grab a quick soup or salad before bed, the hotel restaurant will not be able to provide that for you.Otherwise would recommend this restaurant to my friends and family for sure!

Apr 26 2007	Clean and neat but tiny rroms	My wife and I recently attended a play in SF ("Jersey Boys", terrific) and wanted a reasonably priced hotel in the theatre district; the Beresford Hotel filled the bill. The staff was polite and helpful, the included breakfast was about what you'd expect: cereals, sweet rolls, some fruit, coffee and teas. Mar 13 2007 	Good stop but only for a day...	Being the first time I have ever visited San Francisco, I chose the Beresford for it's reasonable price and convenient location. Next time I go to San Francisco, I will stay somewhere else even if I have to pay a little more.

Feb 16 2007 	Great value for the location	My husband stayed at the Hotel Beresford for a weekend stay in San Francisco. This hotel is in walking distance to Union Square. This hotel was great for a short trip in San Francisco. A breakfast of cereals, fruit and pastries is provided in the adjacent pub each morning. The rooms are supplied with nice soaps and the shower is the strongest I have ever seen. The room had a television with just a few stations. We were able to park our car at the hotel for around $24/day. However, it did take some time for the staff to take the car and we were concerned about getting a ticket as we parked at a meter just outside the hotel. Jan 29 2007 	more than adequate	the hotel beresford was perfect for us. nice room, very nice bathroom, above average continental breakfast, helpful staff, perfect location for exploring sf.

Oct 11 2006 	Clean with OK breakfast	Two blocks down from the Union sq, also a couple of blocks away from China town.Safe and comfortable area for walks any time. Oct 4 2006 	Everything we needed at a bargain price!	At a "Manager's Special " price of $106 from the hotel's website, we had low expectations, but booked because of the location and price. It turned out to be a great stay- our room (519) was at the back of the hotel- very quiet . The decor is rather Victorian with red carpeted halls and gold and white walls covered with historic photos.. Our room was small but spotless and had everything one could have needed. There was a fan in the closet if required as most hotels in SF don't provide air conditioning, which is almost never needed. Our room had a bed, 2 nightstands, 2 chairs and a side table between, a 5 drawer chest and a tv on a stand. We had a small clean bath room with a stall shower but no tub, which we didn't require. There were nice toiletries provided , as well as a mini fridge fully stocked and even two real wine glasses.The hotel was so quiet we almost swore we were the only occupants, but we met some other travellers in the morning at the continental breakfast served in the restaurant. Three types of cereal, crissants, assorted pasteries, oj and a variety of really prime fresh fruit ( most mornings, apples, bananas, oranges. dates and fresh strawberries) as well as coffee, tea and chocolate were more than adequate for us. Every employee we encountered smiled and greeted us warmly. The hotel is convenient to Union Square - we walked the few blocks from the BART Station with our roller bags and took a bus back from the Ferry Building one day that stopped at the door.I can't think of anything we would have changed about our stay. There are numerable well known restaurants within a few blocks ( like the famous Sears) and the immediate area is home to an art school , so lots of galleries and the like. We felt perfectly safe walking around.If you have traveled in Europe and understand and appreciate small, well maintained , budget hotels, you will appreciate the Beresford. We'd return without question.

Oct 4 2006	Good location but basic.	Stayed here 3 nights as part of tour group. Was given wrong key and I went into someone elses room! Then given key that would not work. Sep 29 2006 	Great little hotel near Union Square	San Francisco hotels generally represent good value. I came to that conclusion recently after searching for a hotel in New York for a trip next year. My room at the Beresford was $98. No doubt the same room in NYC would go for $250-300. Even a 4-star hotel in SF costs less than a room in an average hotel in Manhattan. But anyway, getting back to the Beresford: I've stayed in several hotels in the Union Square area and this was the nicest experience I've had. The hotel is in an old 7-story building in a great neighborhood, next to the Marines Memorial Theater and a 5 min walk to Union Square, Chinatown or Market Street shopping. Very friendly service from all staff members. A nice mix of guests, some on business and lots of tourists. The hotel seemed pretty quiet at night but just to be safe I requested a room on the top floor at the back, and had a great night. My room was small, about 10 x 10, but ample room for a solo traveller. Carpet was a bit worn but all furniture and fixtures were in great shape. On a hot summer night the room might get a little stuffy--there was a fan stored in the closet for this purpose. There's a great little tavern and restaurant on the premises. I didn't have dinner there but I enjoyed eating breakfast the next morning at a table with a view of Sutter St. The breakfast wasn't much, just cereal fruit pastry and juice, but it was adequate. Overall I would recommend this hotel to anyone--except families on vacation. For groups of 4 or more I would seek larger quarters. But for anyone else this hotel is a great choice.

Jul 21 2006 	As Expected	After reading many reviews on the 'net, we decided to try the Beresford Hotel. Since we were just meeting a friend and needed a place to sleep, I wasn't looking for anything fancy. Generally, the hotel was exactly what I expected. It is an older hotel, but the staff was friendly and it is in a great location. Upon arrival, we were asked to double park in front of the hotel while the valet parking attendant arrived (15-20 minutes). It was traffic hour and we did not feel comfortable doing this, so that caused some tension for the employee who was in charge of this....but he found a place for us in front of a nearby garage temporarily. Other than that, all employee's were very friendly. The hotel looks nice even though the decor has not been refurbished for some time. Going up to our room, there was an "old" smell. I am very sensitive to smells, so this was a little bothersome for me. My husband said he liked it and it reminded him of his grandparents home. The decor of the hotel is outdated: older - but good quality and clean carpet, wall paper, etc. Our room was clean. We asked for two twin beds because this hotel does not have King or queen beds, and the two of us on a double just didn't sound good. The beds were comfortable, more so for me I think, as I am small. The bathroom was basic, but fine. There was shampoo, conditioner and soap available. I asked for a QUIET room, as I don't like to be interupted when I sleep, so they put us on the 6th floor facing a non-vehicle alley which was, indeed, quiet. Breakfast consisted of Cold cereal (3 choices), whole fruits (oranges, apples and bananas), tea, coffee, juice and cocoa, and pastries (croissants and swirl fruit-in-the-center type). The surrounding area of the hotel is fine - I felt perfectly safe walking at night.Overall, the hotel is fine for an overnight stay. If you are expecting plush new accommodations where you will enjoy hanging out in your room, this is not the place for you. But if you are ok with the basics, this hotel will do. San Francisco usually has somewhat higher prices for hotels, so for the money this place is acceptable. In the future if I had the time, I would keep looking for a better deal, but if this is where I ended up I would be ok with that too.

Feb 9 2006 	clean but minimal	We just returned from the Hotel Beresford which is well located near Union Square. The hotel was worn, but fairly clean. The room was tiny. The queen sized bed had shabby linens and a creaky headboard. The small bathroom had a shower, with no bathtub, shower cap or even a hair dryer. The staff was pleasant, however we had to wait a long time for our car, and parking was $20 extra. There is no air conditioning so we had the windows wide open, which was great except for the construction crew that started working very loudly, just below our room at 7:30 am. We've stayed in San Francisco a lot - you can do better than this.

Feb 7 2006	Great Room Great Price	My wife and I went out to San Francisco on our honeymoon. We stayed at the Hotel Beresford for three nights. Our corner double room was ideal for us. While the room was smallish, it was all that we needed. The bed was a very comfortable Queen. Mainly what we liked was the price. With our AAA discount the price of the room was less than $90! For a hotel just off Union Square in San Francisco that was a steal. The room came with a complimentary continental breakfast and the service in the hotel was first-rate: the concierge was helpful and effecient, check-in and check-out were both handled with no fuss and the cleaning service never missed a step.The cons for this hotel are the size of the rooms and the bathrooms in the rooms. We had a small shower with no tub and a very loud toilet, so loud that you couldn't talk while it was filling the tank. This was such a minor problem that it doesn't really affect the review. If you want a good, inexpensive hotel room near Union Square in San Francisco, try the Hotel Beresford.

Dec 6 2005	a horrible experience	I booked this hotel through Expedia when I arrived the room was nothing like I expected close cramped quarters,asked for a view looked out onto a brick wall. My daughter is 32 years old when she went down to get ice they were not the least concerned ablsolutely would never ever ever stay there again Marcia Wagner

Oct 9 2005	Would stay here again	What a find! My partner and I stayed here the last two weeks in September. But it had a great shower (and who needs bathtubs when they're only 5" deep anyway?!), and we never had any issues with low water pressure or availability of hot water.Yes, we had no view but come on, people: what do you expect in the middle of a city unless you stay at a high-rise hotel?The continental breakfast was good as far as we saw as we didn't always use it, although the coffee was sometimes a bit weak.The mini-bar was well stocked and VERY reasonably priced. More to the point, it gave us a fridge to keep our own drinks in.We found the staff friendly and helpful (they even got us a limo at cab prices to go to the airport when we left!); the situation of the hotel is excellent and at $89 + tax we thought it was above average for that price range. (And the price left us lots of $$ for spending, given the /$ exchange rate ;-))The only negative thing about the area was the noise, but that seemed to be almost entirely due to the considerable amounts of building work going on to the west of Union Square, and only affected us - marginally at that - early mornings.We'll happily stay here again.

Sep 22 2005	Good Value for Money	I was a little worried after reading the reviews, but went with it as I am budget-minded. True, the hallway smelled funky, but I noticed the same smell emanating from other older hotels as I walked by. (Hotel Beresford was built in 1911). The hall windows were opened & closed each morning by the staff to help. No air con, but there was an unusual cold snap & A/C wasn't needed. The heat was supplied by what looked to be the original steam radiators-quite an interesting sight for this Floridian. The room was a bit small. Bathroom was shower (no tub). The window looked out at the building next door, but I don't book a room based on view. One computer with free access for all-other guests were quite reasonable and shared so it was not a problem checking e mail a couple of times. And the White Horse Tavern has a meat loaf that we talked about for 2 days-it's different but delicious! The front desk & all other staff were pleasant and accommodating. Had to transfer to another (more expensive) hotel for business and within 24 hours was wishing for the unpretentious atmosphere of this place. I would stay here again.

Sep 21 2005 	Highly Recommended	I'm staying at the hotel right this minute and it is a God-send. Only vacancy I could find near Union Square and not only is the price really great ($89 a night), but it is nice. Most pleasant, beautiful lobby, marbeled elevator, what looks to be a newly renovated room. The staff couldn't be nicer or more helpful. The area is good, since the Hilton is just a block away. Nicely stocked minibar at the most reasonable prices I have ever seen. Rooms are very clean, and mine is quiet and peaceful. I highly recommend it, and I'll probably stay here every time I have to visit SF from now on. Valet parking is $20 a night, about average for SF, and they sure make it easy to leave your car -- it's quick. If this is a budget hotel, then they should all be this nice. The room has more room than I was expecting from other reviews. There is a seating area as well as all of the basics. The bed is really comfortable.

Aug 24 2005	Good for location price etc.	All the negative reviews of this hotel are off-base! You pay $89-$125 a night and expect Waldorf Astoria ambiance and service. The rooms are on the small side but this is ten times better than any of the cheap-y motels by the airport and if you are really cheap there are a ton of hostels in the area! San Fran part two	Average overall but was fine for our needs. Thought we would be in a Japanese hotel but really just a refurbished hotel from the 80's with japanese decor. Nov 18 2009 	A Great Place with Kids	My husband and I stayed at Hotel Kabuki-formerly Hotel Miyako-During chilly July 07 with our 3 month old and my mother. Our first family vacation and it was wonderful. At first I was hesitant to stay in Japantown, just ignorant really, but it was such a nice surprise!  Finding the hotle was a snap, but parking was valet only $35/day at the time. Check-in took about 5 minutes, really quick, and the elevator whisked us up to our rooms. We stayed in a Deluxe View Corner King room with a beautiful view-instead of curtains we had shoji screns for window coverings which are excellent blackout screens. My mom was across the hall in her own King room with a view. We were visiting during a construction phase, but you would never know. We seemed to be separated from any guests, I think we were the only guests on our floor, and that was fine with us-peace and quiet with our baby! They provided a crib for us, just a basic drop side, and since she didn't move around at all, we were not worried about crib recalls. The King bed was huge, bigger than a normal king-maybe a California King :) and we slept very peacefully in the nice bedding and pillows. The TV was nice, but I think they have updated to LCD TV's since our trip. The bathroom with the huge/deep soaking tub was a treat. Even the baby enjoyed her Japanese baths!The restaurant/lounge was not open during the construction, so we went to the mall and ate at BennyHanna's and the Sushi Boat in the Miyako Mall. The area outdoors is very nicely manicured: Peace Garden and Koi Pond. and there are several shops, restaurants (Pizza, Denny's), art galleries within walking distance, but be aware that it is hilly and steep, 4-6 blocks feels like 10 on those inclines! The amenities were scarce when we were there, no spa or in room services, no pool-still no pool, but we did have wireless internet and a morning paper.Very Kid friendly hotel: always greeting us and asking if we needed anything for the baby. And we did end up buying formula/diapers at a local Japanese market-just like a local Dallas maket with more Japanese variety, but they did carry Similac and Pampers. We walked a lot on the trip and San Fran in general is a great stroller city. Wine country/Napa not so much. Who takes their baby on a wine tour anyway?!? That's right we did, but it was OK.All in all, I would love to go back to see the updated version of this property. It was very nice and clean and steeped in Japanese decor,and I would like to see all the new amenities and room improvements.

Nov 16 2009 	Lovely hotel in Japantown	We chose the Kabuki for a short visit to San Francisco as it is away from the noise and confusion of the central city area. Staff was pleasant and accommodating. We will definitely stay in this hotel again.

Nov 16 2009 	Room size layout view and furnishings were excellent as is its location.	After staying in several San Francisco hotels during the past 15 years while visitng our daughter, we've settled on the Kabuki as our best choice, particularly since its renovation and expansion a couple years ago. Nov 15 2009 	Always a pleasure	We stayed here last week for my birthday. The front desk upgraded me to a bigger room without me asking. The parking is very reasonable and safe at 16.00 a night. There are so many shops and delicious places to eat. I am always more than happy to stay at Hotel kabuki. The rooms are stunning and the service is outstanding. How can you beat the amazingly romantic views from your window. This is the place I most like to stay when I'm in San Francisco.

Oct 30 2009 	First of Many Future Stays at Hotel Kabuki	Charming Japanese style hotel in charming Japan Town. Painted screens create huge murals on the walls, and roll back to reveal huge windows. We also didn't get the welcome tea and agree the breakfast buffet was forgettable, but still appreciate the friendly service and great value.Don't miss the amazing restaurant Bushi-Tei across the street. Expensive but worth the splurge for incredibly fresh, delicious and creative dishes. So many charming little restaurants, shops, bookstores to discover in this area. We had a strenuous but much needed Thai massage nearby. Did I mention that this area is so charming?! :)
Oct 30 2009 	Fantastic hotel	Great hotel, close enough to the action. This Japanese-style hotel had great rooms. Everything was spotless and the staff were extremely helpful and courteous.

Oct 12 2009 	Cheap makeover Big disappointment	I was initially very excited to book the Kabuki, having become addicted to JDV hotels, the Vitale in particular! Disgusting dirty windows and old metal sliding door which didn't slide, in fact one wouldn't open at all! The balcony was no more than 1ft deep with dirty fake grass matting all over it.The air filters looked so dirty we slept with the door open at night rather than use the aircon. Oct 9 2009 	OK experience...Offered more than they could deliever...	Location in Japan Town was excellent and close to great food and culture. Hotel was OK but nothing out of the ordinary. Oct 8 2009 	Fabulous place in Japantown	We stayed here with our 6 and 9 year old boys in a corner king room with a rocking view of the city and sliding door that opened along two walls. Oct 8 2009	Lovely but glad we had a discount code	Found a great rate via their facebook page & so glad we did...Pro: wonderful location, comfy bed with crisp linens, great shower pressure & a nice flat screen / Cons: smaller than expected room (fine but low frills & nowhere near five star) & no soaking tub, so be sure to ask if that's what you wantOverall, a lovely stay, especially for the price & will definitely return when in San Francisco. Oct 8 2009 	A Japanese Experience in the Heart of San Francisco	We enjoyed a wonderful stay at the Hotel Kabuki. The service was friendly and warm when we arrived to the hotel. The hotel is located next to Japantown which provided us good restaurants and shopping.

Oct 8 2009 	Loved the Kabuki!	We got a good deal on a pre-paid room at the Hotel Kabuki and were very satisfied. We had a corner room on the 10th floor with great views of the city. The location was nice, it was an easy walk to Union Square, but far enough that it was much quieter. Lots of great Japanese restaurants in the area. Oct 8 2009 	If you find an internet deal grab it and enjoy your stay at an upscale Japanese hotel	Through an internet special, we got a "deluxe view king room" for $85/night, and for that price, our stay was amazing.
