The hotel staff were very kind, and our room was elegantly decorated. Our only complaint was that the shower head was pretty low, so watch out if you're on the tall side! We ordered room service one morning, and the food was fine, but nothing compared to the places we ate out at other mornings. I would definitely stay there again if I could find a comparable deal.

Oct 7 2009 	Never again!	I go to San Francisco fairly often for business and usually stay at the JW Marriott. Just for a change of pace, I thought I'd try the Hotel Kabuki because it advertised Japanese style rooms AND FREE INTERNET ACCESS. I also signed up for the Joie De Vivre program (their version of the points program) before booking. They have you fill out a form listing your preferences, including whether you'd like water, white wine, or red wine upon arrival. I don't drink, so I selected water. But when I arrived, I was told that I only had a choice of wines -- that the hotel was out of water! How can a hotel be out of bottled water?! So I asked if I could just have a Diet Coke, but the front desk said "no". I was told that if I wanted a Diet Coke or bottled water, that I could purchase it from the Honor Bar. So they promised water (can this be more simple?), claim to be out, then say that I have to buy it from the Bar. It gets worse. I booked the Japanese suite. The hotel advertises free internet access and internet access is a must for my business. Only there was no cable in the room and the wifi had very limited range. I spent an HOUR on the phone with various levels of tech support, all to no avail. They finally moved me to another room, where I finally had sporadic internet access. The Japanese theme is quaint, but the rooms are very outdated, bathroom tiles are chipped, even the top of the toilet was chipped. I'm 5'7", but the shower head was WAY too low, and yet the sink was so high that I had to stand on my toes to wash my face! The bathroom looked like it hadnt been updated since at least the 1980's. The only "cute" thing about it was the flip down scale (I thought it was a radiator). That must be from the 1950's. One of the tatami mats had a huge worn through area.

Oct 6 2009 	Great Value for reasonable price	When we first got into San Francisco, we booked "The Mosser" hotel. It was in primal location, but rooms were tiny...very tiny. Every morning getting dressed was a struggle. So we decided to look for somewhere else, and that's how we moved into Hotel Kabuki.For $30 more for one night, you get ten times of comfort. The rooms are much much bigger. It can fit in a king size bed, a writing desk, a full size bathroom with separate shower and bath, and there is still ton of room to spare! Now we can finally lay down both luggages and still able to walk around.It's only 10 minutes bus ride to Union Square. With the 3-day Muni passport, we don't have to worry about getting the exact change. Also the hotel is very close to a major road "Geary", so buses are frequent, we rarely have to wait for more than 5 minutes for a bus.  The King size bed with 400 thread count sheets was so comfortable, every night we have slept like babies since we got here. Bathroom has a nice decor, but the hot water for the shower takes a round 3 minutes to actually get hot - but that maybe it's just our room? There are tons of restaurants around here - mostly Japanese food. It's in Japantown after all. A lot of cute shops nearby where you can get some Japanese arts and crafts. It's a quite neighborhood, definitely not as lively as Union Square, but why would you want to hear other people partying when you go to sleep?

Oct 2 2009 	Wonderful Hotel	We had a wonderful time here. We stayed during the week, meaning prices were lower and we got a 4-night deal so it was even less. We had a room on the 16th floor and we could see the Golden Gate on a clear day, beautiful view. Parking is relatively cheap compared to the rest of the city, they have a garage next door with direct access to the hotel elevators at $16 for 24 hours. For the rest of the trip we took advantage of the MUNI system (google "MUNI 511" for planning which ones to take that day) which was pretty easy and had several stops near the hotel for ease - we went to Alcatraz, the Golden Gate Park, the Bridge, Union Square, the Port, Market Street, Fishermans Wharf, and Ghirardelli Square using MUNI. Theres also a Safeway nearby for a cheap dinner in your room. Lots of restaurants nearby as well (mostly Japanese of course). The fridge in the room is kinda small but does fit breakfast items to save a litle money. The shower was really cool, just keep your towel/clothes off the floor or they will be soaked. My one complaint is that we could not control our own room temperature, or at least we couldnt figure out how. We are warm sleepers and it seems the hotel has the system switched to "heat" after a certain hour, which was no good for us (it was also September, still mildly warm outside). So we slept with the sliding door cracked and window covers pulled passed it. This also meant a little more noise coming in - I put cotton in my ears. Also, you share a balcony with the room next to you, so be careful about that. The room itself is cozy, if a little tight. But we were out all day so who cares. The bed and pillows were wonderful, we both loved it. They are pet friendly and we had our cat with us and they did not charge us a pet-fee (they may for dogs). The only reason we would not stay here again would be to experience somewhere else, though this hotel is just outside of "downtown" and so was quieter, but still within easy reach of all the things you want to do. :-) Oh yah, free internet too. And they did discontinue room service.

Sep 27 2009 	A hotel in a quiet place submerged in a small local culture	At the end of a long day of urban hiking, returning to the Hotel Kabuki was like "coming home." Sep 25 2009 	Great Hotel with Great Service	This Hotel met all my expectations. We stayed in a corner room which was very roomy and had awesome views of Japantown and surrounding areas. Sep 17 2009 	Relaxing stay	I really liked this hotel. Loving all things Japanese just added to the pleasure from the Japanese gardens on the property to the location in Japantown. Sep 15 2009 	Quite and Safe	I loved that the hotel seems to be in a quiet and safe location. Good sized rooms and bath rooms. The only thing that really bothered me is the amount of mold behind the overflow drain in the bathtub. Ew.

Sep 15 2009 	Good place great service 1 hiccup	Beautiful property in the middle of Japan town. Hotel staff was always helpful and pleasant. Sep 5 2009 	Unique comfortable hotel in good location	I stayed there 3 nights with my husband, 4 year old son and 20 year old nephew. The front desk staff was friendly and helpful. Sep 5 2009 	Nice end to our Roadtrip honeymoon	Bought our stay online 4 days before we arrived in San Francisco at the end of a month long coast to coast roadtrip. But we were leaving for the airport that morning and therefore didn't return it due to time but i'm sure it wouldn't have been a problem as the service was excellent!The restaurant is worth a visit and the menu is a japanese/western mix... I can recommend the burger!We used the valet parking as we had a hired mustang convertible and wanted it looked after, the other parking is a short walk away, looks safe enough but we decided not to take that chance! Aug 31 2009 	Great stay at a great location	We stayed 5 nights in this Japanese style hotel with Japanese touches such as the green tea and shoji screens and deep tub and nifty shower. Aug 19 2009 	Very Nice and a Good Location for Little Ones	We enjoyed our 4-night stay at the Kabuki. We did not hear any street noise (even car alarms) or the service elevator across the hall, the room was well insulated and shared a narrow balcony with the room next door. The room had an electric kettle, teabags instant coffee and a traditional cast iron Japanese tea pot and cups for tea. There was an afternoon sake tasting but we did not attend. The Desk Staff pointed out the convenient coupons and discounts on the Japantown parking website. My only complaint would be if two share the room the lack of a door into the bathroom area casts a light into the sleeping area, you are unable to light the wc without the dressing area light going on and waking other sleepers. Aug 16 2009 	Perfect getaway for a honeymoon! Aug 10 2009 	Overall not so great...	We were really excited to stay here because of its location (its in the center of Japantown), however that was pretty much the only good thing about it. Needless to say, it isn't the best place to stay if you want privacy from family members, etc. when you are showering. On the first night there we had absolutely no hot water. We informed the front desk of our problem and they could offer no suggestions. They sent up an engineer who said that "everyone must be taking a shower at the same time and that is why there is no hot water." And then he asked us, "Oh, you like your showers hot?" Well, duh! We waited an hour and tried the tub again. Still no hot water. This time the front desk offered to give us a key so that we could walk to a separate building to take a hot shower. Seriously? We paid to stay in a hotel room with a hot shower, why should we have to walk someplace else for a hot shower? Not to mention that we had paid extra to have a soaking tub, which in the end we couldn't use anyway. So in the end we all took cold showers and didn't use the tub until the next morning. Overall, the soaking tub was a waste of money and the service was sub-par. The location was the only decent thing as there is mall access in the hotel lobby. If you are looking for somewhere really close to Japantown, look into Hotel Kabuki. If that doesn't matter to you, definitely try someplace else.

Aug 10 2009 	Not impressed with Kabuki	I was excited to stay at the Kabuki after reading the reviews on Tripadvisor and getting a great rate through hotwire, and having stayed there for 4 nights, I can say that I'm very disappointed with the overall stay. This made me worry about the rest of the room's cleanliness. We had only one robe, and no wash clothes. Housecleaning had to bring them up for us at our request apologizing that they just got out of the dryer, and the robe looked like it just came out of the dryer all wrinkly. We complained and got a room in the adjoining building with no balcony, though the room was about the same size. That night a group in the hotel decided to party on their balcony at 3:00 in the morning and were shouting down to the courtyard which echoed into our room. Aug 7 2009 	Great Hotel in a Great Neighborhood	We booked an awesome deal for the hotel and were so pleasantly surprised to find how nice the hotel and the neighborhood of Japantown was... Aug 7 2009 	Relax at Kabuki	So nice to have a nice hotel to stay in after Yosemite. Centre of Japan Town.Nasty $16 daily parking charge. Everything else was fantastic. Bit of a distance from downtown SF but a good base for travel.Staff were so nice and polite.

Aug 5 2009 	Great Hotel Good/Safe Location Highly Recommended for SF First Timers	This is the first time we visited San Francisco, and we're so glad to have chosen this hotel as a great introduction to the city! Japantown is not too far from the main San Francisco attractions, yet not too close to the noisy, overcrowded streets of the more popular parts of the city. It is a very safe & clean place to walk around, and there are plenty of Japanese restaurants, grocery stores, and gift shops steps away from the hotel. The hotel accommodations we great - the room was very clean and looks just like the pictures from the hotel's website and the king size bed was very comfortable. On our floor it was pretty quiet - we did not hear other travelers at night, but maybe because we stayed on weekdays. We visited the main attractions using public transportation and walking. There are a couple of bus lines very close to the hotel, depending where you want to go. If you look at a map of San Francisco, you will see that Japantown is only 10-15 minutes away by bus to most major attractions. We also used our GPS to find good restaurants/shops and were delighted to find that you can get to them within a 2 mile radius. The doorman and staff were also very helpful in arranging taxi or helping you figure out which bus line to take. We would recommend first time travelers to San Francisco to get the city pass (available on SF's visitor website), which includes passes to main attractions and 7 day, unlimited pass to all the bus/muni/trolley public transportation.

Aug 4 2009 	A great very safe location and nice hotel	We stayed for 4 nights in an 'Executive Sauna Suite' which comprised 2 rooms and bathroom with sauna. If you have a car, this is a good place to stay as there is parking in an independent underground car park which has a lift up to the hotel lobby, for $16 per day. The room was comfortable, especially the king size bed, not so much the sofa-bed. There was a balcony overlooking the Peace Pagoda. Aug 3 2009 	Relaxing stay	Hotel Kabuki is conveniently located in the heart of Japantown in San Francisco, right next door to the Japan Center (filled with great Japanese restaurants, cafes and shops), close to a movie theater and not too far from Union Square (take bus nr 38 from Geary str). The bathroom had a Japanese soaking tub with bath salt to enjoy it. Aug 1 2009 	i'll be back	i loved this hotel, the staff were friendly, the room was lovely and the bed very comfortable. the japanese bath was brilliant. toiletries supplied [especially the soaps] were of excellent quality and there was an abundance of towels. i'll be back.

Jul 31 2009 	Ideal location for anyone visiting San Francisco.	The room we got was for $80.00 through Travel Ticker and you couldn't ask for better. Our room had two walk-out balconies on the tenth floor that had phenomenal views in either of those directions. The room looks just like it does in the picture, with lots of nice touches like the chaise longe and the print screens that allow you to let in light or the bamboo shutters that can close over the screens to completely darken the room. The lobby is lovely with it's view of a Japanese garden and many places to sit in. I used the well-equipped exercise room that also has a view into part of the garden. It was cold in San Francisco and the hotel had a fantastic A/C to crank up the heat. My teenage daughter was in paradise because the Japan Town mall is only a few hunded feet away and was full of Japanese restaurants, knock-off jewelry, bag shops, Manga and anime stores and a wonderful hair salon to get her hair cut in a Japanese style. I enjoyed walking over to this mall every morning to get my coffee along with a freshly-made Japanese pastry shaped like a fish, with a wonderful filling. Across the street from the Hotel Kabuki is a restaurant called Sanppo that we ate in a couple of times which had great atmosphere, the best tempura and seafood soba. The staff there are very friendly and thoughtful. We were within a 20 minute walk to the Union Square part of town and from there took a 20.00 double-decker tour bus that took us all over to the tourist sites and where you can get off and on as often as you please for two days, not a bad deal. In that Union Square area there's a lot of shopping, but it was like our tour bus guide said, "Neiman Marcus, otherwise known as needless mark-up." The line to get into the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art went around the corner when we got there. But what we saw inside was well worth the waiting. It was a great vacation for us.

Jul 30 2009 	Excellent hotel in a great location	My wife and I really enjoyed staying at the Hotel Kabuki for the three nights we stayed in San Francisco. The Japantown mall is immediately adjacent to the hotel, and there is a convenient underground parking lot just below the hotel. The hotel is also close to the Upper Fillmore area with its many restaurants, shops, and casual eating areas - a great area to simply wander before or after dinner.

Jul 28 2009 	Love this place	Sometimes you can get a great rate, in part because it's not in the center of the usual business/tourist action around Embaradero, Union Square and the wharf. Jul 20 2009 	It was fine but would try another location next time; people polite	We took the San Francisco City Shuttle to our hotel since it was just about to leave and costs $17.00 and brought us directly to Hotel Kabuki. The room was a decent size, but the bathroom was configured oddly, but maybe thats how its done in Japan. There was one sink, full wall mirror, closeted toilet and a combination area with the deep soak tub and a shower alongside. The shower had just enough of pressure to make it ok. This area had a glass door and as such, no one else could use the sink area if you are taking a shower. I never used the deep soak tub on the trip. The clear door which was inches away from the wall mirror would have been better suited to a romantic room. Our balcony door had the pretty shutters which certainly led to having lots of natural light. We never did get the tea service that is advertised on the website, though there was a tea service in the room already. Not a deal breaker, but a bit of a downer. We also found that it was very easy to walk the city from Hotel Kabuki, but we are walkers, so everyone might not think so. We never did take public transportation anywhere, though one did take a cab back twice. All employees we encountered very nice and polite and I loved our doorman. He was exceptionally pleasant and helpful. But one did have to sort of force the front desk for help; there was always a smile, but, I think at times, it should have been provided not have to ask. The answers were always a little tnetative regarding the garage, so if you ahve a car, you may want to get definite conclusive answers. Also, this is a good hotel if you are seeing a show at The Fillmore as it is literally 3 blocks away.

Jul 18 2009 	Nice place to stay	Stayed here for 2 days while in town. Booked the room for about 80USD avg per night through travel ticker deal. This hotel is good value for money. Jul 12 2009 	Meh	Average service. Rooms had interesting decor. Hotel bar ok. Would stay again if the price was right. Parking was expensive and difficult to find. Wasn't fantastic, but not bad either. Price rather expensive.

Jul 11 2009 	Nice Hotel and Location	We really liked the Hotel Kabuki. We got a great rate and it was a great value. Jul 8 2009 	Loved our stay here!	Our room was very clean! The beds were really comfy in my opinion with goose down pillows and the sheets were changed every day! Jul 7 2009 	Nice Location; Convenient; Some nice rooms but a little worn...	A relatively large hotel in a nice neighborhood in Japantown, conveniently connected to the Japantown plaza shopping mall, where there are plenty of good places to eat (Japanese & Asian food, of course) and shop (excellent Japanese bookstore and other shops). The basic rooms, especially the double, are tight. Ours lacked any kind of dresser, which meant we lived out of our suitcases for 5 days; not the most comfortable situation. The Japanese baths (separate shower and deep soaking tub) are a nice touch, but it takes up a lot of room that would otherwise allow for more living space. The rooms in the low-rise section (junior suites, etc.) are much better, though the views are better in the tower. Parking at the shopping plaza is relatively cheap ($15/day) and convenient (direct access to the elevator, straight to your room). No in/out access, though. Jul 5 2009 	This place is fine for a single traveler	The hotel's appearance, from the outside,is fine. However, once in the room, it was on the small side with an oddly-configurated bathroom. Did I mention there was no door separating the bath area from the double bed area? Jun 24 2009 	THE place to stay in SF	We did a lot of research before deciding to spend our 4nights in SF at Hotel Kabuki. In retrospect, this was a great choice!Value - great value with respect to other comparable hotels we had considered. This is a legitimate 3.5 hotel in my opinion, in a great part of the city. We got a great internet rate of $90/night for deluxe-view room, which was lower than any comparable hotels in Fisherman's Wharf, Union Square area, or Embarcadero. Plus, this hotel comes with free internet and in-room fridge; self-parking is only $15/day. Most Union Sqr and Wharf hotels charge $30-$50 parking per day. To boot, they upgraded us to Corner View Room for free!Room - our Corner View Room was on the 10th floor, and it was great. Very spacious room, nice comfy bed, nice bed linens, thick bath towels, clean carpet. As others have commented, the bathroom was magnificent. Separate shower and deep sunken tub next to each other. The tub is just great to soak in. The bath salt that they provide, though, is not that great. You can actually get the real Japanese hot spring bath salts (sold in packaged box) at the nearby store in Miyako Mall called Ichiban-Kan. Those are much better. The room does show some wear and tear in certain spots, but is overall well-kept. The biggest problem was that the free wireless internet had extremely spotty connection.Location - we were under the impression that Union Square or Fisherman's Wharf area might be the best locations in the city. But in hindsight Hotel Kabuki's location worked out the best. The Union Square area has a lot of brand-name stores and is convenient to the BART and to Chinatown, etc. But we were not in SF to check out brand-name stores, and there's a lot of homeless presence in that area. Fisherman's Wharf area is just too hectic and touristy. On the other hand, Hotel Kabuki is connected to Japantown malls which have loads of great Japanese shops and restaurants (recommend Sophie's Crepes for great crepes and gelatos, and Benihana or Mifune for lunch). You can enter the eastern end of Japantown mall directly from the hotel lobby and then walk across the malls out the western end and you'll be right in Fillmore District that has loads of cafes, eateries and shops lining Fillmore St... this is one of the coolest hangout streets in SF. 20minute walk north from the hotel will get you to Union St, another street filled with shops and cafes.Service - the free room upgrade was a major plus. On the down-side, there were many basic things that we had a hard time getting them to supply us with. Like the shampoo... they never gave us new shampoos, even after we ran out on the third night. Another time we needed plates but the front desk told us it'd be a while before we could get them because both the restaurant and the room-service were closed that day and every housekeeping staff was busy. Ended up taking over 30minutes to get a plate and nearly as long to get the extra shampoo. I don't know if the place is short-handed or what. Housekeeping's pretty good overall, but a little bit quirky... like not supplying new shampoos at all and one day giving us less number of towels. But all in all, these were not major issues.

Jun 23 2009 	Nice Place to Stay in Japantown	Stayed here for a week while my daughter was at UCSF. The location was fine since we wanted a place not too far from the hospital. My daughter enjoyed the free wireless internet so she could "stay connected" while on our trip. I did think it was strange though that there was a shared balcony with the room next door. A much better bargain and just as convenient.

(wish it worked for us, though) It would of been nice, since we did walked all day and put many miles walking down those steep hills! So there goes our bath! However the shower head was amazing and that did it for the time being. The rooms were bright and cleaned everyday. Breakfast was offered at the end of the lounge areas, and was awesome to see each morning!If you're wondering about the staff there, everyone is very pleasant. They all treat you as guest, and willing to accomodate any request you have. Even going as far as flagging a cab car for you. (we haven't done this too much, as we come from the midwest!) They are all wonderful people at this hotel. Really, you couldn't wished for any more patient people to be in this hotel than the people who are in it serving you.We did not eat in the dinning area here because it seems kind of spendy, but what do you expect, it's a restaurant inside the hotel. Otherwise there are many other food choices along the street. Lots of cheap and very good sushi in that area.You won't regret your stay here. All the staff will amaze you. A quick cab ride to Union Square will cost you about $7. From there you can walk to many sights, and sees!

Jun 21 2009 	Neat Hotel - Worth a visit	We stayed 2 nights at the hotel. Our flight left at 5 a.m. and we had a rental car, we parked the car on the street in front of the hotel the night before we left because the gararge closed sometime after midnight and doesn't open until 6 a.m. The meters are free after 6 p.m. The staff at the hotel was professional and not rude in any way. When we arrived in the room, the heat was not working, we called and someone came to repair the system immediatley. I am a black female and did not feel as though I was treated unfairly at any time. Jun 9 2009	Quiet Elegance	This is my 2nd stay at Hotel Kabuki. Tower rooms are beautifully decorated, beds extremely comfy and I always enjoy the Japanese-style soaking tubs. Located in Japantown, many awesome restaurants nearby.

Jun 7 2009 	Kabuki is excellent	I love the Kabuki. It's Japantown location is wonderfully tranquil and allows for plenty of low-key walking-distance eating and activities. It is beginning to recapture the feel of its glory days (when it was the Miyako Hotel).

May 17 2009 	A Relaxing Stay	My husband and I stayed here for five night for Anniversary in April and could not have been happier! The hotel staff was very friendly and helpful with recommendations for places to eat in any price range. The breakfast at the hotel was high but good. The free wi-fi was fast and never crashed. May 12 2009 	nice hotel for the price safe location	MY boyfriend is from Texas and had been wanting to go to San Francisco for a while, so I was watching travelzoo for good prices on hotels in San Francisco. May 10 2009 	great value great neighborhood	got a great price online. rooms are large, comfortable, nice sheets, rooms a little worn, but nice soaking tub in room. very good, understated service. i love the neighborhood-japan town bordering on pacific heights-peaceful streets, some of san francisco's best restaurants within a 1 block radius (Kiss Seafood and Quince), Fillmore Street just a few blocks away for breakfast, shopping, restaurants. May 10 2009 	Okay	I'd read a review here that an African American woman traveling alone posted a few months ago. Apr 20 2009 	A nice place to stay...	My hubby and I stayed at the Kabuki as we wanted to reconnect with Japantown, a place with fond memories of long ago. It did not disappoint. We brought our kids in the next day and the staff was very accommodating (they were great all around) and even provided us with a crib. Apr 13 2009 	Spacious rooms	I had stayed here once before when it was the Radisson Miyako and while the name has changed to Kabuki, not much has changed.The king bed room was very spacious and had a balcony that was shared with the room next door. It's mainly a balcony for the view as you only have standing room, but the view sure was nice. The room felt a bit old and new at the same time.The bed was awesome. The room feels nice enough and it's spacious, that staying there is fine and the minibar is stack full of tasy bags of chips, candy etc, good stuff. There is a small desk and a couch as well. The room also a has a small closet space for clothes and a safe, but it has very little vertical space to hang your pants and shirts which was a bit annoying.The bathroom is split into a toilet and then the awesome japanese bath. The bath itself is huge and there's all kinds of different bath salts to try out. It certainly is a great place to relax and the best part of the Kabuki experience. Still, the location feels nicer than downtown with no homeless people roaming around, but if you want to step out of the hotel and get your Starbucks/fast food/shopping fix, this is too far.

Apr 12 2009 	Great hotel great location... awesome rooms! Apr 6 2009 	You had me at soaking tub.	My husband and I spent 4 days in San Francisco, just to get away. When I heard about the traditional Japanese baths, I was sold. Mar 26 2009 	Some good some bad ...	My college-aged daughter and I stayed at the Hotel Kabuki from Friday, March 13th through Tuesday, March 17th. The mini bar (nice touch) had two bags of chips that were past their freshness date. All in all, it was a very nice place to stay, just alittle more attention to detail and maybe some sort of noise cancelling option for the street noise (a white noise machine, maybe). Thanks, though, the staff couldn't be more gracious and we did have a lovely time.

Mar 25 2009 	Not quite like the Miyako but still good...	Hotel Kabuki, formerly the Miyako Hotel, has reinvented itself as part of the JDV hotel group. We all slept very well and we will definitely come back.

Mar 2 2009 	Enjoyable neighborhood and comfortable hotel	We stayed at the Kabuki February 2009 for 5 days. We found the people friendly and helpful and the location great for us, as we love Japanese food, sampling the local restaurants and exploring the local markets. It's located next to the Japan Centre, full of great shops and restaurants in several buildings. We got a nice Internet Special deal, which made the price within a reasonable range. The Filmore district, with tons of jazz clubs, is only a few blocks away, and there is a bus that goes to Union Sq nearby. The Filmore farmers market (walk past the Japan Centre, make a left on Filmore and walk 2 or 3 blocks) is in a lovely outdoor venue on Saturdays with an excellent jazz band playing, a great place to spend a few hours on a pretty Saturday. (Great produce vendors where you can pick up some fruit--Don't miss the Afghani food vendor--you will want to have some of their stuffed bread and sauces for lunch). There is a Starbucks there as well...2 snags on the room: Wireless is an extra charge, and no simple breakfast options for early risers: The hotel's buffet is expensive--even what they call "continental" breakfast, and there is no provision for just getting coffee and a roll or something. The Japan Centre eateries don't open before 10:30, even the deli and crepe place. There is an electric kettle and cups, and a japanese teapot and cups in the room, but no coffee maker and no tea supplies--we had to buy some at the market ourselves. One day we had toast and coffee sent up to the room, and Saturday we ate pastries at the Farmer's Market & got coffee at Starbucks there. We did find a kind of dodgy place a couple of blocks away finally, and had breakfast there--the only customers in the place. That cup of coffee or tea in the morning is important to us!If a visitor wants to see all the major sights, etc., maybe there are more convenient places; we are an older couple with children in the area who take us to events and the parks, though, so we really loved the neighborhood.

Feb 28 2009 	a fantastic experience	When we arrived tired after a 15 hour journey from Scotland the staff from the doormen to the receptionists made us so welcome. Feb 28 2009 	Awesome beds and rooms!	Self-park at the Japantown Parking Garage, just down the hill from H. Kabuki and save $20 on parking. The soaking tub and welcoming tea service were high-end amenities at affordable SF rates! Our new favorite place.

Feb 11 2009 	Jewel in JTown for foodies	I stayed 3 nights in mid January at the Kabuki, a very reasonably priced convenient launch pad to local Japanese restaurants and meeting point with old friends. Feb 9 2009 	Reasonable but disappointing	The room was decent and had been recently renovated to about 80%. The amenities are mostly absent. The hotel resturant/bar "Izakaya Lounge" was excellent with friendly an attentive staff and good quality Japaness style food at reasonable prices. The Hotel breakfast was the usual choice of "Continetal or American cooked breakfast" and was appetising and reasonably priced. The one problem that we encountered was noise, the hotel is not adequatley insulated from street noise (we were on the sixth floor)and internal noise insulation between rooms is also poor. Unfortunatley this alone would effect our decision to stay at the Kabuki again, though younger travellers or night owls would probably not mind this but after a long flight and being jetlagged we did.

Jan 5 2009	Understated well thought-out loved it	My husband and I stayed in a corner king room on Christmas day, and left the car parked in the Japan Town Center lot. Recommended by a friend, and I loved it! Nice designs, simple, understated, but well-thought out. Nice touches: shoji screens in front of sliding glass doors offer privacy, daylighting, and insulation. Way nicer than the typical blackout curtains. Cool wood block print panels decorate the walls. Electric kettle and tea pot in the room. Japanese soaking tub was fantastic.They covered all the things that irritate me about other hotels and the lions-share of American buildings. Little things that I loved: the coat / shoe closet is by the front door; the toilet is separate from the shower and sink; the toilet is mounted on the wall (sans the grody caulking on the floor); there is a drain in the floor of the bath area.If you want something "luxurious", or gigantic this probably isn't the spot for you. But if you want a central location, like going to Japanese shops, and appreciate something different at a fair price, Kabuki is the way to go. I'd say a Marriott is to Kabuki, like a Lincoln Navigator is to a Prius. I dig the Prius, and I loved Kabuki.

Dec 18 2008 	Nice for something a bit different	Clean, small room. Restaurant downstairs was overpriced and doesn't fit with the theme of the place. They charged me for some charitable donation on my bill without asking me. Otherwise a decent place with some good restaurants nearby.

Dec 17 2008	Excellent Value	We stayed at Hotel Kabuki for two nights in the cold of winter for $89 per night which was fantastic value. The room was warm and immaculately clean, with a nice bathroom. The bed was very comfortable, with soft, cosy linen. The staff were helpful. We had a car and parked it in the associated car park for $15 for 24 hours and chose to walk around instead. The hotel is approximately 25 minutes walk to Union square, which we didn't mind at all. If you don't fancy the walk, bus 38 runs along Geary street behind the hotel. Japanese food near the hotel was fantastic. If you don't mind the location, we would highly recommend this hotel for cleanliness and great value.

Dec 2 2008 	Great Hotel Stellar Service!	We stayed at Kabuki last month for my birthday weekend in S.F. It was our second stay there, and will probably not be our last. We found it the first time 2 years ago (then Miyako) because of it's low rate and relative closeness to the things we like but far enough away from the tourist traps that we like to visit but don't want to be stuck in. The rates were a little higher this time around (still cheaper than many comparable hotels we found) but then I got an email that said buy 2 nights get a 3rd free, we figured what the heck and made a long weekend out of it.We love staying in Japantown, it's so much quieter than Union Square yet it's still close enough to take a 5 minute cab ride, or 30 minute walk. The rooms are fantastic, great views from almost any room. Sunken soaking tubs, newer tv's, and free internet! There's plenty of restaurants to choose from nearby--and in the hotel, though we didn't try it the breakfast sounded amazing, we were just on a tight budget and it wasn't the "cheapest" you could find--and great shopping in the Miyako mall.BUT, the best part was the service. The front desk crew was very nice and the doormen would always greet you with a smile. And to top it off, I left a personalized frame I brought with me that my sister gave me, we were in town for a show and the frame held a picture of us with this comedian we were there to see and was personalized with a quote from him so I wanted him to sign it. I left it behind with my ticket stub and remembered it hours after we left. I called and they found it right away and proceeded to FedEx it to me. And they were all so helpful every step of the way, I called more than once. They even carefully wrapped each part of my frame in bubble wrap--it's two separate pieces of glass that sit in a personalized silver frame, all very fragile--and then wrapped it up tightly in a towel. I was very pleased that they took such good care of something that was obviously important to me and couldn't be replaced. I've experienced similar situations at other hotels that didn't even bother to look for my items--albeit much less important items but still.And did I mention the Garden!!! It's truly a beautiful hotel, if you're looking for something off the beaten path and enjoy Japanese food and culture than I would highly recommend Kabuki.

Nov 25 2008 	Eh!	I think it helps to know who writes these reviews, so here is some basic information: My husband and I are in our mid - late 30's. We like HIlton, Marriott-type of hotels and also like to splurge on hotels and nice B&B's when given a chance. Here's the review:It was fine. It seemed like a converted Holiday Inn. The shower was great, there were robes in the room, which we love. However, our toilet ran the entire time, we were promised a complimentary tea service that didn't come both times we ordered it and a dirty food tray from our next door neighbors sat outside our room for at least 36 hours before being picked up. All the customer service people always seemed overwhelmed.We wanted to park in the lot associated with the hotel, but it was full both times we tried. So, we parked in a garage the hotel recommended and was attached to the hotel. Nothing went right with it - the automatic payment machines didn't work. And, then we were told the garage opened at 6:00 a.m. on Sunday (we had to leave at exactly 6:00, probably a little earlier to return a rental car and make a flight). As we were making our way to the garage, a hotel guard told us the garage wasn't open till 7:00 and that we would have to pay him $50/cash to open the gates. We kept pushing back because it sounded fishy and then we asked someone at the front desk who told us the garage opened at 6:00. We went to the garage and waited for someone to open the gate and they said the garage didn't open till 6:15. We begged him to open the doors early and let us out because we were already late for flight - thank goodness he did.I would not return to this hotel and would have given a lower rating, but for $109/night in San Francisco, it was o.k. with us.

Nov 22 2008 	Great Location 	Conveniently located on Geary Street, we enjoyed a wonderful stay at the Hotel Kabuki. The hotel is recently renovated, and its minimalist Japanese architecture and furniture actually worked exceptionally well for us as we were traveling with our two toddler sons. After being couped up in an airplane or our rented car our sons loved the wide open spaces in our two room suite. From the moment we arrived, the staff was very attentive to our needs. The valet parking our car asked me my name only once, and from that point for our entire four night stay we were greeted warmly by name every time we arrived or left. The hotel operator cheerfully handled our three year repeatedly calling her (to our horror!) The rooms were clean, and the queen sized bed we had was one of the most comfortable hotel beds we have ever slept in. The Kabuki is nicely located close enough to all the major sites in San Francisco, with exceptionally convenient access to the highway as well.All in all we were very satisfied with our stay, and look forward to visiting again.

Nov 18 2008 	Love that soaking tub	Great neighborhood, great concept and great service at the Kabuki. We had a corner king room with a soaking tub and separate shower. The room is huge with two large sliding doors with sliding japanese screens and sliding covers, so privacy and quiet from street noise is excellent. Many nice touches, tea set, wall insets, divan, robes, etc.Granted the furnishings aren't the newest and the sliding door did not close all the way, but this in no way lessened our enjoyment. Not every single thing has to be brand new to work well. That said, new flat screen TV was excellent with free internet provided as well. Elevators came instantly and pleasant shopping abounds in surrounding Japantown. You can usually find overnight parking for free on the street if you wake by 9 or you can park in an adjacent garage for $15.00 per night. Full valet parking is $35.00 per day if you are a high roller.Don't forget to ask for a room on a higher floor to enjoy excellent views. One problem though, in asking for directions I mispronounced the hotel name as "Bukaki" and was met with guffaws for some unknown reason.

Nov 14 2008 	Hotel Kabuki a modern theatrical opera	The Hotel Kabuki is reminiscent of a Japanese theatre.On the surface it has all of the glam of a modern theatrical opera, but once you stay awhile you realize it's an opera that's seen its hey day. 1) The so-called newly-renovated guestrooms look like they were renovated in the late 80s -early 90s. You should see the huge stereo t.v. in the club lounge. It definitely will not work when digital t.v. comes to town. Also, the fitness center needs an upgrade.2) There is false advertisement on the hotel brochure-The courtesy shuttle is not always reliable. -the 24 hr. business ctr. has an inoperable printer,so don't count on using it! In fact, count on being chargedextra to use it. (long story...)-the complimentary wine (sake) hour doesn't exist, sobuy your own wine elsewhere.On the flip side, the hotel is quiet and has somecharms like the Sjoji window screens, traditional tea in room, and Asian bedding.Just remember that the hotel needs some TLC (tender loving care) and hopefully one day the Hotel Kabuki will shine again!

Oct 17 2008 	Overvalued hotel	Even though they remodeled the hotel. it is still far to be 31/2-star hotel. you don't have any controls on air conditioning and heating systems. Just hope you're in right season to avoid these problems. the front desk won't tell you this until you check-in... be aware...

Oct 7 2008 	Adored the Kabuki	We stayed in the Kabuki unfortunately only for one night at the end of our trip across CA and we absolutely loved it, the hotel itself, the theme, the room, the gardens, the food was delicious, service brilliant and we will be back there as soon as we can , a treasure in SF :)

Oct 6 2008 	Best Bathrooms 	I stayed in the double room for a few nights in September, 2008. The bathroom was the best I've seen outside Tokyo and Seoul. Beyond the large area for the sink and toilet, the shower was in another alcove behind a glass door. There were multiple showers (2 shower heads on opposite walls and 3 body sprays near one of them), there was a tile bench along one wall that you could sit on while you took a shower if you chose the removable showerhead opposite the one with 3 body sprays. The bathroom was almost as large as the bedroom. The beds were also extremely comfortable. Service was immediate and friendly. The bath products were from Lather, and they smelled wonderful. I go to an annual convention in San Fran, and this is the first time I've stayed almost my entire time in the hotel- I took a couple long showers daily and read in bed all day. Although I stay at different hotels every year, I will book at the Kabuki from now on. This room was so nice that I'll book better rooms in the future. This is not like any of the other 4 star hotels. If you care about the 2 things top on my list for a hotel- the bathroom and the bed, you won't go wrong at the Kabuki.

Sep 29 2008 	the Kabuki was very pleasant	I researched for days to visit during one of the busiest times of the year, I was looking for unique, away from the hustle bustle of union square and I found it at the Kabuki. We chose the Corner KIng and we had lovely views of the city. The decor was minimalistic and serenely Japanese and lovely. The hotel staff was very professional and accomodating. The parking was great...you must expect to spend at least 25-35 dollars to valet park in this city anywhere. The staff: the hosts, bartenders and valets, ad housekeepers were all very accomodating. The Japanese tub was super. The Kabuki was simply...a very pleasant stay.

Sep 24 2008 	A great place to stay in SF!	Hotel Kabuki in San Francisco's Japantown is a great alternative to the often over-crowded and over-priced hotel scene near Union Square. Sep 22 2008	Good hotel but a little out of the way	Stayed for a Saturday night in September. Am a fairly recent visitor to SF ans know my way around reasonably well though I'd never stayed in Japan Town before....and to be honest I doubt I'll stay in the area again. If you want to be close to 'downtown' you're better staying elsewhere.The hotel isn't the cheapest although the views from the corner room were quite impressive.The public car park is reasonably priced and easy to access as the hotel has an elevator directly to the underground levels, ask nicely and the hotel will even validate your ticket even if it's not included in your room rate :)

Sep 8 2008 	Great Room - Loved the Bath 	We stayed for one night and asked for a King Corner with the special tub. The room was clean and spacious with a very comfy bed. The tub was terrific and felt amazing. We got a room on the 13th floor (note that the ice machines are on even numbered floors) and loved the view. Great location.

Sep 4 2008 	Hotel Kabuki Excellent for Price	In San Francisco third week of August 2008--booked three star hotels via Priceline--two were excellent; one was bad. Highly recommend Hotel Kabuki and Kensington Park which you might get on-line for $100-$125. Beware hotels "under renovation" or no-frills, "Boutique". Don't want to identify the latter hotel because manager was so nice, but arrived with 3 TV channels, spotty wi-fi, faced a brick wall, mold. Hotel company (SF has Personality Hotels, Kimpton, Joie d' Vivre, etc.) did book me into much better accommodations.

Sep 1 2008 	Perfect for us	We stayed at the Kabuki in Japantown for three nights while interviewing for jobs. It was perfect for us: not too fussy or ostentatious, but nice touches like very clean, new sheets and bedding (supremely comfy beds) and toiletries and friendly staff. I was worried it was going to be over-the-top with the Japanese theme, but it was tasteful and not at all like the amusement park I feared it would be. We had a really nice view (we were on the 12th floor facing North) and it was a nice to be in a convenient yet calm and not noisy part of town. Free wireless, decent tv. Wonderful deep Japanese-style bathtub, eucalyptus salts provided. This is no fancy dancy hotel, but it's clean, comfortable and the details are attended to. Also very convenient to buses. The restaurant was good (with the exception of the Udon that I got from room service) and the hostess went out of her way to help us. The little pond with koi fish was tiny but a nice touch.We got a cheap bundle deal of plane plus hotel from Travelocity.
Aug 31 2008 	Great place to stay in japantown	The rooms are spacious with great Japanese bathrooms and breakfasts. I would recommend this place especially if you can get a good deal on the room rate.

Aug 28 2008 	Doesn't worth the price at all!!!	I stayed three nights at the Kabuki Hotel. The room is not what you would expect for a 270$ / night. The windows were old and didn't close properly so the room was noisy. The balcony was shared with all the floor and even they have a sticky on the window saying that was safe to left the window open.The first day they began to clean the room but forgot to finish it. They left the wet and dirty towels over the bed, and did'nt clean the room. I also asked a hight floor with views three months before my arrival (to avoid street noises) and all I've got was a second floor room.I payed a supplement to have "citi views" and therefore I was expecting a nice room in the tower but all i've got was the second floor with views to a secondary street.I found a lot of Motels, even in in San Francisco, with better rooms, better services and for less than a 1/3 of the price.

Aug 23 2008 	Lousy	I expected a quality hotel with excellent service. I am sorry to say that the stay was not worth the money, the service was in one word: lousy. It did not even meet the service of a 1 star hotel. So the Joie de Vivre story of experience this and that is all bla bla to me if you cannot even achieve the basic standards of service.

Aug 21 2008 	Excellent bed but better stay in Union Square	I stayed here for 4 nights at the end of july because I like Japanese stuff but these is not really Japanese, just a few pictures and decoration. Excellent bed and bathroom, very clean and very near Japantown shopping mall and restaurants and Fillmore restaurants at walking distance. You can take the bus 3 different busses to Union Square, the bus stop is really near and it's just 8 minutes.Cold welcome and behaviour from receptionist.Part of Joy de Vivre Hotels, which are really lovely and should recommend.

Aug 17 2008 	Once is enough	Good location, very comfortable beds, good restaurant breakfast, mostly courteous staff, beautiful garden; however, the room was hot (no air conditioning), they charge for Internet use in the business center, television had very few channels, bathroom area not private enough. Glad I stayed there, but will only do once.

Jul 28 2008 	Some Style Limited Substance	I'm not that impressed with Hotel Kabuki as I wrap up a four-night stay in a recently renovated room. A longtime resident of San Francisco before moving abroad, I heard good things about this hotel when it was known as the Miyako. It seems quality has been compromised some since then. It should be known that the hotel's location is a good one. On the edge of SF's small but charming Japantown, it is close to major bus lines on both Geary Boulevard and Van Ness Avenue. The smartly appointed hotel lobby and courteous Front Desk staff provided a great first impression. The room itself was also nicely decorated and gave the feel of a bonafide boutique hotel. But problems cropped up almost immediately. The toilet was not at all clean, basic complimentary amenities were missing (and remained missing well after housekeeping passed through the next morning; I only secured the amenities once I asked for them directly), and the guest robe hung in the closet had fresh make-up stains on the inside from a previous guest. The television remote control was missing, and when I called to get a replacement was grilled by the Front Desk agent about whether or not I had done a thorough search of the room for the remote control rather than be told another would be sent up straightaway. The hallways proved noisy in the evening, and a neighbor's half-eaten dinner ordered through Room Service remained on the hallway floor for well over twelve hours. Otherwise, one of the two doormen seemed to do everything possible not to make eye contact with entering and exiting guests. Not exactly hospitality in action. In isolation, each one of these problems seems minor. But together, they point to the fact that Hotel Kabuki is more style than substance ... especially given the price.

Jul 23 2008 	A Taste of Japan	We stayed at the Kabuki because our first choice wasn't available... luckily! Because we really liked the Kabuki. The reception was fast, helpful, friendly, professional. The place itself was calm and peaceful and well appointed. And the room, a corner room (1111) was small but perfect. We had views of the city, a small balcony, a nice Japanese tub in the bathroom and a very comfortable bed. We were able to easily use the internet from our room. We had drinks and h'ors d'ouevres downstairs, which were delicious. And then we ate dinner across the street at bushi-tei, which was also very delicious. The whole experience was enjoyable, beginning to end. And we liked the towels so much, we bought two of them to take home!!

Jul 18 2008 	Better place to spend money	We stayed there three days ago for one night and vowed we will never go back.We were looking forward to staying there and we chose this place to spend our last night of our trip in San Francisco.The welcome tea ceremony that was promised never took place. The room was smelly and when I went to wash my face I saw the finger nail on the basin. Yuk.The Internet connection was bad. Took 10 mins to open a webpage. You need to connect and reconnect repeatedly.Then next morning when we went to have breakfast in the hotel's restaurant it took more than 10 mins for someone to take the order. Had I not voiced out my displeasure it might take more than 20 mins. I saw a family whose father also lost patience becasue of the same issue.There are many better places in San Francisco to stay, definitely not this one. We so regreted of making such decision and decided to pst this message so other people will not have to go through what we experienced.

Jul 17 2008 	Loved This Hotel	Our friends and we were attending a wedding in SF and found it quite a challenge to find a reasonable hotel. So, in our search, we found Hotel Kabuki. The men are not especially adventurous and they wondered if a Japanese hotel would be very different. Well, we booked it and were very happy we did. The parking was easy (though we did use the valet parking), the rooms were very clean, the Japanese decor was striking and the staff were as nice as can be.The sheets were so soft and the pillows were great also. The bathrooms were way above standard with some of the baths including an entrance shower to the tub. Bath salts were included as were directions on how to take a traditional Japanese bath. When we returned from dinner and entered our room, a guest had broken the rule and smoked somewhere and it was just drifting into our room. I called the desk and they moved us without delay and gave us a $15 dollar each credit for breakfast. The restaurant in the hotel was exceedingly expensive and the food was not very good. The cod I got tasted like wonder bread (still cannot figure this out), the hamburger was great, the drinks were also grossly overpriced, the morning coffee to go for $3.00 could be obtained across the street for $1.75 (in the mall) and the omlettes were overcooked and dry. The room did have free instant coffee. My husband and I would not eat at this restaurant again.But the hotel - we would go in a heartbeat. The experience was great fun. Have a good time!

Jun 29 2008 	Could be a very special place with some improvements	The Joie de Vivre hotels group, of which Hotel Kabuki belongs, impressed us greatly when we stayed in their Domain Hotel in Sunnyvale. That hotel was bright, new and modern.  The Kabuki in Japantown has some of the same qualities, although with a very Japanese style of decor. The lobby is pretty impressive, and the staff is polite. We had a Deluxe Corner room on the 15th floor, to take advantage of the bird's-eye view from our balcony. We enjoyed the view, and were lucky to witness the "Critical Mass" demonstration/celebration (depending on how you view it) take place right below our windows. The elevator is lightning fast, but the ride is very smooth. The sliding screens over the windows/balcony doors in our room with Japanese illustrations on them, the black framed furniture and the Japanese-style fabrics gave the room a distinct feel. The traditional soaking tub did as well, although we did not use it that way most of the time (we preferred to shower). The bed, with a pillowtop surface, was very comfortable. The usual amenities are there -- hairdryer, safe, refrigerator, shampoo and conditioner. The kimono-style robes were a nice touch, though the robes seemed a bit old. So the style was as we'd hoped, but the rooms are a bit worn and in need of remodeling. There is a hot pot in the room for boiling water for tea, and a set of tea cups and a small tea pot. Providing only two tea bags seemed a bit stingy, though. There was no coffee maker however, which was disappointing to my husband. Even though this is in the heart of Japantown, most Americans still like to have coffee in the room. The tiny frig was so full of honor bar drinks, there was no room at all for leftover food we brought to our room. One thing I wish the room had was a door to the bathroom sink area. The toilet is in its own room with a locking door, and there is a wall separating the bathroom/toilet area from the main room, but the shower stall door is clear glass, and a lack of another door there takes away some of the privacy, especially if you want to shower or wash at the sink while you have someone visiting your room. A door to the area would also minimize noise from someone using the sink or shower that might disturb someone else sleeping in the bed.  The hotel needs to improve its concierge service. The staff directs guests to the doorman on duty for this, and the doormen don't seem to know much. We asked about getting to Golden Gate Park and where to park, but the doorman neglected to tell us about the no-left turns on most streets and the many one-way streets. He also left out the fact that the Asian Art Museum in the Park has a huge parking lot, and instead told us to park on one street south of the park. So our drive there was very frustrating. The next day, we asked the doorman (a different one) about getting to Point Reyes to the north, and he had no idea what that was or how to get there without looking at a map. And he had no maps to give to us. Even if the hotel may be catering to business people, they should know how to advise guests on tourist activities. We booked the room by calling the hotel directly, and got a great deal at $150 avg. per night (this was for June 2008). My relatives staying in the hotel paid almost as much through Expedia for a smaller, less interesting room. Parking in the nearby municipal garage was $15 per day, which is $10 less than the hotel's garage rate, and $20 less than in the Fisherman's Wharf area. The hotel is in a nice area -- especially Fillmore St., with its many small shops and restaurants. And there is no lack of Japanese restaurants in the neighborhood. We also like the Soko Hardware Store across the street on Post, and the Ichiban (Dollar Store-like) store in the attached mall. If they remodel, upgrade some of the amenities, and improve their concierge service, this hotel will be quite wonderful.

Jun 24 2008 	What a treat!	My daughter read about this hotel on this site and talked usinto staying there. Such a great experiance... beautiful area(we'd never been to Japantown and really enjoyed it) thehotel is beautiful and the rooms heavenly. The Komono robeswere a surprise we weren't expecting. Also after checking inthe front desk called up to ask if we had everything we neededand to tell us about the evening tea... just call the front deskif we'd like to have complimentary tea between 6 and 9. We did and it was wonderful loose leaf tea served to usin a little tea pot with glasses and honey with lemon.The rooms were beautiful we had a view of Japantown, and beautiful rice shoju screens and painted japanesewomen on the wooden screens. It's a family favorite now..if I had one slight complaint it would be the shower set upcould be a tad more private. We'll definitly be back!!!

Jun 19 2008 	Weekend trip	Went to SF for the weekend, stayed 2 nights at Hotel Kabuki. It is a beautiful hotel. The bed was very nice. However I had called ahead of time and was told that our room would be the double double with a view and balcony in the tower part of the hotel just like I had reserved online. When we arrived we were told that we were changed to a family suite (an upgrade) but it was in the garden part of the hotel and on the first floor where we had a view of passing cars and no balcony or outside air. When I asked to change rooms the women at the front desk just stammered and stared at their monitors. The air conditioner didn't work so it was very hot in the room. Valet parking was a joke, $25.00 a night and I was told on the second night that I couldn't park there even though there were empty places. Found the staff to be not very friendly and never said thank you or looked us in the eye. I paid a lot of money for a room that I didn't want and was upset the whole time.

Jun 2 2008 	Cool Hotel for a Unique SF Experience	My family (2 adults, 2 teenagers) stayed at the Hotel Kabuki for one night in April, 2008 in order to get an "out of the ordinary" experience and give the kids a taste for what a Japanese hotel is like. The hotel was quite nicely decorated, conveniently connected to a Japanese mall full of Japanese stores & restaurants, and the soaking tub in the bathroom was a nice plus!The kids stayed in a queen size bed in the living room while my wife & I shared a large futon in the tatami bedroom. Both were nicely appointed, and the tatami room reminded me of some hotels I had stayed in in Japan - authentic and comfortable. We even found a sauna in our bathroom just before we checked out - too bad we didn't know sooner that it was there! We didn't eat at the hotel as we felt the breakfast was somewhat overpriced (had I been there on business I might have eaten at the hotel), but we had a decent dinner at one of the many Japanese restaurants in one of the adjacent shopping centers, and we had breakfast at one of the coffee shops in the mall as well. As an added plus, I took advantage of the free use of the Kabuki Spa before checking out. It was a wonderful experience, with a variety of tubs and a great steam room and very relaxing Japanese music. I was there for about an hour, but I could have stayed for at least one more. The hotel was on the expensive side, but it is San Francisco, and we sprung for a suite with the tatami room - a more conventional room with 2 beds would have been less expensive. the tatami bedroom was very cool

Jun 2 2008 	A great place to stay central to everything.	This hotel came highly recommended to us. We wanted to stay a few days in the Japan Town area of San Francisco for a few days when on holidays. The property has recently undergone renovations and is nicely done. The rooms are still a tiny bit dated, but the product in the rooms, especially the beds (kings beds, with feather duvets, amazing egyptian linens) They have a restaurant on site (Japanese and western style food) A must to experience, the servers in the dining room go out of their way to service you. There is a ton of restaurants and shops right across the street and in close walking distance to the hotel.The wharf, pier 39, shops are close, you can hop on a trolley just 10 minutes from the hotel and head to all the attractions at the wharf.Would for sure recommend this hotel as a place to stay when in San Francisco.

May 29 2008 	Beware Room 411	Overall, we had a nice stay. I got a good deal on Travelocity airfare/hotel package at Hotel Kabuki. We checked in on a Wednesday afternoon, we were given our keys for room 411. At first glance, the room looked ok; that was until we opened the curtains and looked out the window. All we could see were cement walls and the restaurant exhaust system - an ugly, rusty sight. When we looked straight up, we saw a tiny bit of sky.I went back to the front desk and politely asked if we could change rooms and have one where we could actually see something out of the window. The hostess asked if we needed a king bed or a japanese tub. I told her that we could do with a queen bed and the japanese tub was unnecessary. She said she would upgrade us at no cost to a King room on the concierge floor with jetted tub. We checked into room 2504. It was very pretty with a big, wide window with rice paper screens that opened to reveal a view of the city in both directions and the hotel Japanese Garden below. The jetted tub was very large and deep.Concierge floor means complimentory continental breakfast. Thursday morning at 7:30 they set up coffee, fresh fruit, large sweet rolls, cereal, milk, and juice. Friday morning - no continental breakfast, not even coffee. We were in a hurry to go sight seeing so we didn't bother asking. Saturday, Sunday, and Monday, they left a sign in the breakfast area saying that there would be no continental breakfast but we could pick up a voucher at the front desk to use in the hotel restaurant. The voucher was worth $12 pp and was to be applied to our restaurant bill. The breakfast food was good. One day the service was very slow and the next day it was fast.We enjoyed our room and the hotel. We loved the Japanese decor, modern lobby, and Japanese Garden. Japantown is a little bit out of the way from tourist attractions but is on a main bus line so transportation was easy and convenient. We enjoyed the serenity of Japantown after the fast pace of downtown. The area was clean and the malls and stores were fun and interesting.

May 26 2008 	Delightful Oasis in Japantown	After arriving at the hotel from a late flight, I was informed at check-in that I didn't have a reservation (no thanks to my administrative assistant who forgot). Nonetheless, the front desk person, Sherman, was very helpful. The lobby is just beautiful and room is an oasis from the hustle of the city. Our conference facilities were excellent. The bar and restaurant are exceptional. I would highly recommend this hotel.

May 24 2008 	Wonderful Hotel	Booking: I contacted the hotel directed to make reservations. It turned out to be less than any website. We paid $112 for each room a night, however, it was on weekdays. Checking In: We arrived an hour early and to my surprise they had our rooms ready immediately, which was nice since we had been traveling all day.Interior: I loved the Japanese theme of the hotel yet it still remained western enough to not feel like it was over board. Simple and elegant. RoomsKing Room: Nice and clean. The only thing is that it is a bit small to have any visitors, but its perfectly fine for just two people.Deluxe Double Room: Once again very nice and clean. We love the little sitting area. Since there were 7 people traveling (only 4 stay at the hotels), we used this room as a hang out place at times. Service: The front desk was very accommodating and answered any questions that we had. Housekeeping always did a wonderful job with the rooms. Valet however was not always available but parking was easy.Amenities and Dining: Since we were not in the hotel during the day very often, I cannot review on the amenities or the restaurant . We wish we could have taken advantage of what the hotel had to offer but there is so much to do in SF. We love the little mini mall that is attach to the hotel especially Ichiban USA. It is a wonderful place to buy little snacks and souvenirs for friends and family. So inexpensive and fun.Places to go in SF:-Check out Coit Tower at night and during the day if you have time.-We had dinner in North Beach one night, which is highly recommended.-One of our favorite activities was taking a small road trip to Stinson Beach. From San Francisco after crossing the Golden Gate Bridge, take Hwy. 101 North approximately three miles to the "Hwy. One, Stinson Beach" exit. Follow the signs and enjoy your drive down one of the most scenic highways in the nation. Stinson Beach is approximately 20 miles from San Francisco. Make sure you stop at Muir Beach Outlook, you won't be disappointed.

May 19 2008	Hotel Kabuki- Exceptional	I would like to commend you for having such a wonderful staff at the Kabuki. And w/ that, Ive also got my clients and colleagues to stay there before & we all have the same praises for you guys. Ive stayed at your establishment a couple of times now and I must say, they raise the bar each time - most especially your front desk team, namely Mr. Reyes. As we all know, warmth and fine customer service is part of the industry but he definitely adds more of a personal value into it, & that separates you guys from the clich. Its one thing to get the aesthetic qualities covered but its definitely another to combine it perfectly w/ exceptional service. Keep up the good work and looking forward for another hassle free stay at H.K once again!

May 8 2008	Kabuki Just Right	We stayed at the Kabuki for one night only on our way to New Zealand but we wished we could have stayed longer. All the staff we encountered were friendly, courteous and hospitable in true Japanese style. The room was comfortable; the hotel was quiet;the general ambience was one of peace and relaxation. We also appreciated the Japanese Garden. It was our kind of hotel. We hope to to stay there again and would like to try other "Joie de Vivre" Hotels in the future if there are up to the same standard as the Kabuki.

Apr 17 2008 	Very nice and fair price	This was a very nice hotel. It was in the Japanese area of the city and the staff were very accomodating. I had a king room with a view and the view itself was worth it. I overlooked the TransAmerica building to the left and the bay to the right. Truly breath taking. The price online at the hotel website was the most reasonable that I could find and it was under other hotel costs in the area. Since it was a business trip I had limited time and was not able to travel to the off-site bath house however the soaking tub in the room was amazing. I thiink that the hotel would be very comfortable for Japanese visitors as well. The menus contained half American dishes and half Japanese dishes. There were other nearby dining options if neither suited you. The only 2 things I was unsure of were whether I received club points for the Joie de Vivre membership I got right before booking my trip and whether someone was to come to the room with tea service (since I had this impression from a pre-stay email from the hotel). Neither of these factors affected my feeling about the stay whatsoever.

Apr 6 2008 	A really nice alternative.	We had a week in San Francisco for a convention and decided to take our two kids. That meant looking for a suite, so that we could put the kids to bed in one room and still stay up and watch TV and visit with friends in the other. The Kabuki had a variety of reasonably-priced suites that fit the bill, for just a bit more than a regular double room at the big-name convention hotel. (Note: the Kabuki's 'East-West' suite, with one Western bedroom and one Japanese tatami room, does not adequately isolate one room's sound from the other.) The 'Junior Suite' was great for our purposes. The kids had the big bed in their room while we had a foldaway futon in ours.The hotel is newly remodeled (it was the Miyako when I lived out there), and very comfortable. The staff seemed to be changing constantly, so it was hard to find a regular, 'go-to' person; however, everyone was professional and pleasant enough.Japantown is a nice part of the city, with plenty of (mostly Asian) dining options very close to the hotel. We found we could walk pretty much everywhere we wanted to go (we made the obligatory tourist trek up over Hyde Street to Fisherman's Wharf and even walked to the Tea Garden in Golden Gate Park). When we needed cabs, they were easy to find.The only drawbacks I can think of were the lack of any sort of bathrobes in the room -- a bit odd for a Japanese-style hotel -- and the rather slow wireless Internet. Also, refrigerators in the suites would be nice (NOT just for the idiotic mini-bar -- does anyone actually buy that overpriced crap?) However, all in all, we would gladly go back, and we were very glad we opted for the Kabuki over the mega-chain conference hotel.

Apr 5 2008	Very Nice Hotel with good location in Japantown	We recently spent 3 nights in this recently renovated and renamed hotel in Japantown. It was our second stay there and both times we got a very nice "view room" with lots of room, good views of San Francisco, and a Japanese bath. The staff was very friendly. Both times we enjoyed promotional rates which were very good for San Francisco. This time the service was somewhat lacking--we didn't get our complimentary welcome wine or our daily newspaper. Also a couple items were missed during the room cleaning one day. Breakfast service in the bar was very slow (and expensive) both times we tried it. But overall it was a pleasant stay at a good price.

Apr 5 2008	Four-star prices without four-star service	I recently stayed at the Hotel Kabuki and found it, in a word, disappointing. The hotel is nice, that much is for certain, but patrons are not offered four-star caliber service to match the hotel's four-star prices.Upon arrival, I had expected to receive help with my two large suitcases and three personal bags, but there was no one to be found at the door---no doorman, no bell hop, nothing. I towed my luggage to the front desk, and while check-in was swift, I was not offered assistance with my bags. Worse, I was given insufficient directions to my room in the "Garden Wing" and found myself lost within five minutes of checking in to the property. I returned to the front desk and was given better directions by a different attendant. Had I not been saddled with so many bags, this episode might not have even registered as a negative...as it was, by the time I got to my room I was annoyed and fatigued.First impression: The room itself was billed as an "Executive Sauna Suite." It consisted of two large rooms: a sitting/work area and a bedroom with attached bath and sauna. Though the rooms had recently been remodeled, damage had already set-in and made parts of the room look dingy. The paper on the shoji screens was ripped in several places, scuff marks dotted the walls, and the ceiling looked like it had been repaired and repainted several times. It was obvious that many of the flat surfaces in the bathroom had been somewhat shoddily re-faced with granite, rather than entirely replaced. In short, the room was nice, but far from perfect.Details: The Ipod dock was nice, but there was a dearth of convenient outlets for charging my laptop, phone, and camera. Adequate, comfortable bedding was appreciated. The toiletries were okay, and the towels were fluffy and only a few bore stains from previous users. Two flat-screen television sets featured a small number of stations from which to choose. With the drapes open, the room was nice and bright. During the evening hours, even with all the lamps on, the room was annoyingly dim. The lighting in the bathroom was the worst I have seen in some time. Most four-star hotels provide its occupants with some kind of lighted magnifying mirror for grooming, but not Hotel Kabuki. As a result, morning tasks were more difficult and more tiresome than they needed to be. Overall, the hotel was quiet. I only heard my neighbors a few times. Free wi-fi was nice when it worked. Special Bathroom Note: The bath area was separated from the sink area, which was also separated from the toilet. There was a door separating the bedroom from all of this. Each area had its own door, and privacy was never a concern. Room Service: Avoid the hotel's room service at all costs. It was overpriced, of course, and of exceedingly poor quality. I ordered dinner, which was only mediocre, and, on the day I checked-out, I ordered a scrambled egg breakfast which was inedible. The eggs were sulfurous and undercooked, the sausage was disgusting, the pastries were lacking, and the coffee was bitter. Worse, it was delivered by hasty staff interested not in presenting the meal but in collecting the tip. There is an art to room service that this hotel has not mastered. I assume the Denny's across the street would have been a better bet for both food and service.Housekeeping: Housekeeping was efficient and adequate. No complaints. (And no interruptions.)Business Center: I found it annoying that the business center;s computers are not free to use. Printing on their network looked to be a hassle, so I took my laptop to my room and wrote out information longhand.The day I checked out, a bellman was available to help with my bags and make first contact with my driver. That was an improvement.I doubt I would stay here again...unless I had a significant discount. The Kabuki wants to be a four-star hotel, but until they master the art of hospitality and true service, they will not deserve that rank.

Mar 30 2008 	Nice Room Poor Service	We got the executive suite with a sauna for a really good price during the middle of the week. The room was great, with a few minor details missing. The bath could use a new caulking and the dry sauna didn't get very hot (needed the steam to make it hot). The phone didn't work in the bedroom and after telling them, no one came to fix it. Which gets me to the service... When we checked in, we were not told to go up different elevators than in the lobby, so that was annoying. We were not offered the tea service. We were on the club floor with free breakfast. The coffee was empty and after asking the front for more, they never brought it (even 45 minutes later!). The location was great and the room was quiet. If we had a cheap room here, we would probably stay again, but this time won't expect 4 star service to go with the four star room.

Mar 26 2008 	A 4 Star plus in my book!	This is a very nice hotel and should be rated 4 star. The staff is friendly and they have a free wine reception each evening in the lobby. The room was extra nice on the 5th floor club level. Breakfast was included on that floor also. Location in Japantown was very nice and unique. Also there were no bums laying on the sidewalk and begging like you see at the downtown hotels. A cab to Union Square is $8 or the Muni bus runs about every 5 minutes past the hotel on Geary and only costs $1.50. I will be sure to return to the Hotel Kabuki next time in San Francisco.

Mar 22 2008 	great location we'll stay there again	A friend recommended this hotel and we were not dissappointed. Great location and easy access to public transportation. Our room had a great view, was spacious, the bed was comfortable, and the japanese style bathtub was fantastic to soak in after a day of climbing all those hills. Our only complaints are minor ones: when we arrived no one seemed interested in helping us with our baggage and the room decor seemed to be a stranage mishmash of Asian and Western style decor, but that's just being picky. Try to get a room with a view, and take advanatage of that deep Japanese style soaking tub.

Mar 21 2008	good option	Good value for money city hotel. Can access the city via public transport with little difficulty but use the local bus route map. Althought it is not "down town" it gives options to get to other parts of the city. The Japantown area is really good if you are into that thing. The hotel is comfrtable and cannot be faulted. Bar is excellent. Would I recommend , yes I would.
